editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: THE Kind KEEPER; OR, Mr. Limberham: A COMEDY: As it was Acted at the DUKE'S Theatre BY His Royal Highnesses Servants.
Written by JOHN DRYDEN, Servant to his Majesty.

q.l: Hic nuptarum insanit amoribus; hic meretricum:
Omnes hi metuunt versus; odere Poetas.

div.p: LONDON: Printed for R. Bentley, and M. Magnes, in Russel-Street in Covent-Garden, 1680.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE JOHN Lord VAƲGHAN, &c.
div.p:
I CANNOT easily excuse the printing of a PLAY at so unseasonable a time, when the Great Plot of the Nation, like one of Pharaoh's lean Kine, has devour'd its younger Brethren of the Stage: But however weak my defence might be for this, I am sure I shou'd not need any to the World, for my Dedication to your Lordship; and if you can pardon my presumption in it, that a bad Poet should address himself to so great a Judge of Wit, I may hope at least to scape with the Excuse of Catullus, when he writ to Cicero:
Gratias tibi Maximas Catullus
Agit, pessimus omnium Poeta;
Tanto pessimus omnium Poeta,
Quanto tu optimus omnium Patronus.

I have seen an Epistle of Fleckno's to a Noble-man, who was by some extraordinary chance a Scholar; (and you may please to take notice by the way, how natural the connection of thought is betwixt a bad Poet and Fleckno) where he begins thus: Quatuordecim jam elapsi sunt anni, &c. his Latin, it seems, not holding out to the end of the Sentence; but he endeavour'd to tell his Patron, betwixt two
Languages which he understood alike, that it was 14 years since he had the happiness to know him; 'tis just so long, and as happy be the Omen of dulness to me, as it is to some Clergy-men and States-men, since your Lordship has known that there is a worse Poet remaining in the world than he of scandalous memory who left it last. I might inlarge upon the subject with my Author, and assure you, that I have serv'd as long for you, as one of the Patriarchs did for his Old Testament Mistress: But I leave those flourishes, when occasion shall serve, for a greater Orator to use, and dare only tell you, that I never pass'd any part of my life with greater satisfaction or improvement to my self, than those Years which I have liv'd in the honour of your Lordships Acquaintance. If I may have only the time abated when the Publick Service call'd you to another part of the World, which in imitation of our Florid Speakers, I might, (if I durst-presume upon the expression) call the Parenthesis of my Life.

That I have always honour'd you, I suppose I need not tell you at this time of day; for you know I staid not to date my respects to you from that Title which now you have, and to which you bring a greater addition by your Merit, than you receive from it by the Name; but I am proud to let others know how long it is that I have been made happy by my knowledge of you, because I am sure it will give me a Reputation with the present Age, and with Posterity. And now, my Lord, I know you are afraid, lest I should take this occasion, which lies so fair for me, to acquaint
the World with some of those Excellencies which I have admir'd in you; but I have reasonably consider'd, that to acquaint the World, is a Phrase of a malicious meaning: for it would imply, that the World were not already acquainted with them. You are so generally known to be above the meanness of my praises, that you have spar'd my Evidence, and spoil'd my Complement: should I take for my common places, your knowledge both of the old and the new Philosophy, should I add to these your skill in Mathematicks, and History, and yet farther, your being conversant with all the Ancient Authors of the Greek and Latine Tongues, as well as with the Modern, I should tell nothing new to Mankind; for when I have once but nam'd you, the World will anticipate all my Commendations, and go faster before me than I can follow. Be therefore secure, my Lord, that your own Fame has freed it self from the danger of a Panegyrique, and only give me leave to tell you, that I value the Candour of your Nature, and that one Character of Friendliness, and if I may have leave to call it, kindness in you, before all those other whick make you considerable in the Nation.

Some few of our Nobility are learned, and therefore I will not conclude an absolute contradiction in the terms of Noble man and Scholar; but as the World goes now, 'tis very hard to predicate one upon the other; and 'tis yet more difficult to prove, that a Noble-man can be a Friend to Poetry: Were it not for two or three instances in WHITE-HALL, and in the Town, the Poets of this Age would find so little incouragement
for their labours, and so few Understanders, that they might have leisure to turn Pamphleteers, and augment the number of those abominable Scriblers, who in this time of License abuse the Press, almost every day, with Nonsense, and railing against the Government.

It remains, my Lord, that I should give you some account of this Comedy, which you have never seen, because it was written and acted in your absence, at your Government of Jamaica. 'Twas intended for an honest Satyre against our crying sin of Keeping; how it would have succeeded, I can but guess, for it was permitted to be acted only thrice. The Crime for which it suffer'd, was that which is objected against the Satyres of Juvenal, and the Epigrams of Catullus, that it exprese'd too much of the Vice which it decry'd: Your Lordship knows what Answer was return'd by the Elder of those Poets, whom I last mention'd, to his Accusers.

q.l: Qui tum denique habent salem ac leporem

div.p:
But I dare not make that Apology for my self, and therefore have taken a becoming care, that those things which offended on the Stage, might be either alter'd, or omitted in the Press: For their Authority is, and shall be ever sacred to me, as much absent as present, and in all alterations of their Fortune, who for those Reasons have stopp'd its farther appearance on the Theatre. And whatsoever hinderance it has been to me, in point of profit, many of my Friends can bear me witness, that I have not once murmur'd against that Decree. The same Fortune once
happen'd to Moliere, on the occasion of his Tartuffe; which notwithstanding afterwards has seen the light, in a Country more Bigot than ours, and is accounted amongst the best Pieces of that Poet. I will be bold enough to say, that this Comedy is of the first Rank of those which I have written, and that Posterity will be of my Opinion. It has nothing of particular Satyre in it: for whatsoever may have been pretended by some Criticks in the Town, I may safely and solemnly affirm, that no one Character has been drawn from any single man; and that I have known so many of the same humour, in every folly which is here expos'd, as may serve to warrant it from a particular Reflection. It was printed in my absence from the Town, this Summer, much against my expectation, otherwise I had over-look'd the Press, and been yet more careful, that neither my Friends should have had the least occasion of unkindness against me, nor my Enemies of upbraiding me; but if it live to a second Impression, I will faithfully perform what has been wanting in this. In the mean time, my Lord, I recommend it to your Protection, and beg I may keep still that place in your favour which I have hitherto enjoy'd; and which I shall reckon as one of the greatest Blessings which can befall,

closer.signed:
Your Lordships most obedient,
faithful Servant,
JOHN DRYDEN.

list.item: 1. ALdo, an honest, good natur'd, free-hearted old Gentleman of the Town.
2. Woodall his Son, under a false Name; bred abroad, and new return'd from Travel.
3. Limberham, a tame, foolish Keeper, perswaded by what is last said to him, and changing next word.
4. Brainsick, a Husband, who being well conceited of himself, despises his Wife: Vehement and Eloquent, as he thinks; but indeed a talker of Nonsense.
5. Gervase, Woodall's Man: formal, and apt to give good counsel
7. Mrs Saintly, an Hypocritical Fanatick, Landlady of the Boarding-House.
8. Mrs. Tricksy, a Termagant kept Mistress.
9. Mrs. Pleasance, suppos'd Daughter to Mistress Saintly: spightful and Satyrical; but secretly in Love with Woodall.
11. Judith, a Maid of the House.

div.head: ACT. I. SCENE I. An open Garden-House; a Table in it, and Chairs.

sp.speaker: Woodall.
sp.p: BId the Foot-man receive the Trunks, and Portmantu; and see 'em plac'd in the Lodgings you have taken for me, while I walk a Turn here in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Gervase.
sp.p: 'Tis already order'd, Sir: But they are like to stay in the outer Room, till the Mistress of the House return from Morning Exercise.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What, she's gone to the Parish Church, it seems, to her Devotions.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, Sir; the Servants have inform'd me, that she rises every Morning, and goes to a private Meeting house; where they pray for the Government, and practice against the Authority of it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And hast thou trepan'd me into a Tabernacle of the Godly? Is this Pious Boarding-house a place for me, thou wicked Varlet?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: According to humane appearance, I must confess, 'tis neither fit for you, nor you for it; but, have patience, Sir, matters are not so bad as they may seem: there are pious Baudy-houses in the World, or Conventicles wou'd not be so much frequented: Neither is it impossible, but a Devout Fanatick-Landlady of a Boarding-House may be a Baud.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I, to those of her own Church, I grant you, Gervase; but I am none of those.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: If I were worthy to read you a Lecture in the Mystery of Wickedness, I woul'd instruct you first in the Art of Seeming Holiness: but, Heav'n be thank'd, you have a toward and pregnant Genius to Vice, and need not any man's instruction; and I am too good, I thank my Stars, for the vile employment of a Pimp.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then thou art e'en too good for me; a worse Man will serve my turn.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I call your Conscience to witness, how often I have given you wholesom counsel; how often I have said to you, with tears in my eyes, Master, or Master Aldo—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mr. Woodall, you Rogue! that's my nom de guerre: You know I have laid by Aldo, for fear that name shou'd bring me to the notice of my Father.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, good Mr. Woodall. How often have I said, Into what courses do you run! Your Father sent you into France at twelve year old, bred you up at Paris, first, in a College, and then at an Academy: At the first, instead of running through a course of Philosophy, you ran through all the Bandy-houses in Town: At the later, instead of managing the Great Horse, you exercis'd on your Master's Wife. What you did in Germany, I know not; but that you beat 'em all at their own Weapon, Drinking, and have brought home a Goblet of Plate from Munster, for the Prize of swallowing a Gallon of Rhenish more than the Bishop.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Gervase thou shalt be my Chronicler, thou losest none of my Heroick Actions.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What a comfort are you like to prove to your good Old Father! You have run a Campaigning among the French these last three years, without his leave; and, now he sends for you back, to settle you in the World, and marry you to the Heiress of a rich Gentleman, of whom he had the Guardianship, yet you do not make your Application to him.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prithee, no more.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You are come over, have been in Town above a Week Incognito, haunting Play-houses, and other places, which for Modesty I name not; and have chang'd your name, from Aldo, to Woodall, for fear of being discover'd to him: you have not so much as inquir'd where he is lodg'd, though you know he is most commonly in London: And lastly, you have discharg'd my honest Fellow-servant Giles, because—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Because he was too saucy, and was ever offering to give me counsel: mark that, and tremble at his Destiny.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I know the reason why I am kept: because you cannot be discover'd by my means; for you took me up in France, and your Father knows me not.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
I must have a Ramble in the Town: when I have spent my
Money, I will grow dutiful; see my Father, and ask for more. In the mean time, I have beheld a handsom Woman at a Play, I am fall'n in Love with her, and have found her easie: thou, I thank thee, hast trac'd her to her Lodging in this Boarding-house, and hither I am come to accomplish my design.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, Heav'n mend all. I hear our Landlady's voice [Noise.] without; and therefore shall defer my counsel to a fitter season.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Not a Sillable of counsel: the next Grave Sentence, thou marchest after Giles. Woodall's my name: remember that.

div.p: Is this the Lady of the House?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Woodall, for want of a better, as she will tell you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: She has a notable Smack with her! I believe Zeal first taught the Art of Kissing close.

sp.speaker: Saintly.
sp.p: You're welcom, Gentleman. Woodall is your name?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I call my self so.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: You look like a sober discreet Gentleman; there is Grace in your Countenance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Some sprinklings of it, Madam: we must not boast.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, boasting is of an evil Principle.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Faith, Madam,—

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: No swearing, I beseech you. Of what Church are you?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, of Covent-Garden Church, I think.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How lewdly, and ignorantly he answers!
She means, of what Religion are you?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O, does she so?—Why, I am of your Religion, be it what it will, I warrant it a right one: I'll not stand with you for a trifle; Presbyterian, Independent, Anabaptist, they are all of 'em too good for us, unless we had the grace to follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: I see you are ignorant; but verily, you are a new Vessel, and I may season you. I hope you do not use the Parish-Church.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Faith, Madam—(Cry you mercy; I forgot again!) I have been in England but five days.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: I find a certain motion within me to this young man, and must secure him to my self, e're he see my Lodgers.
O, seriously, I had forgotten; your Trunk and Portmantu are standing in the Hall: your Lodgings are ready, and your Man may place 'em, if he please, while you and I confer together.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Go, Gervase, and do as you are directed.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: In the first place, you must know, we are a Company of our selves, and expect you shou'd live conformably and lovingly amongst us.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: There you have hit me. I am the most loving Soul, and shall be conformable to all of you.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: And to me especially. Then, I hope, you're no keeper of late hours.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, no, my hours are very early; betwixt three and four in the morning, commonly.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: That must be amended: But to remedy the inconvenience, I will my self sit up for you. I hope, you wou'd not offer violence to me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I think I shou'd not, if I were sober.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Then, if you were overtaken, and shou'd offer violence, and I consent not, you may do your filthy part, and I am blameless.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside.) I think the Devil's in her; she has given me the hint again. Well, it shall go hard, but I will offer violence sometimes; will that content you?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: I have a Cup of Cordial Water in my Closet, which will help to strengthen Nature, and to carry off a Debauch: I do not invite you thither; but the House will be safe a Bed, and Scandal will be avoided.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hang Scandal; I am above it, at those times.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: But Scandal is the greatest part of the offence; you must be secret. And I must warn you of another thing; there are, besides my self, two more young Women in my house.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside.) That, besides her self, is a cooling Card. Pray, how young are they?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: About my Age: some eighteen, or twenty, or thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh, very good! Two more young Women besides your self, and both handsom?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: No, verily, they are painted out-sides; you must not cast your eyes upon 'em, nor listen to their Conversation: you are already chosen for a better work.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I warrant you, let me alone: I am chosen, I.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: They are a couple of alluring wanton Minxes.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Are they very alluring, say you? very wanton?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: You appear exalted, when I mention those Pit-falls of Iniquity.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Who, I exalted? Good faith, I am as sober, a melancholy poor Soul!—

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: I see this abominable sin of Swearing is rooted in you. Tear it out, oh tear it out; it will destroy your precious Soul.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I find we two shall scarce agree: I must not come to your Closet when I have got a Bottle; for, at such a time, I am horribly given to it.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, a little Swearing may be then alloweable: you may swear you love me, 'tis a lawful Oath; but then, you must not look on Harlots.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
I must wheedle her, and whet my courage first on her; as a
good Musician always preludes before a Tune. Come, here's my first Oath.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: How now, Mrs. Saintly! what work have we here towards?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside.) Aldo, my own natural Father, as I live! I remember the lines of that hide-bound face: Does he lodge here? if he shou'd know me, I am ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Curse on his coming! he has disturb'd us.
Well, young Gentleman, I shall take a time to instruct you better.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You shall find me an apt Scholar.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: I must go abroad, upon some business; but remember your promise, to carry your self soberly, and without scandal in my Family; and so I leave you to this Gentleman, who is a Member of it.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: (Aside.) Before George, a proper fellow! and a Swinger he shou'd be, by his make! the Rogue wou'd humble a Whore, I warrant him! You are welcome, Sir, amongst us;—most heartily welcome, as I may say.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: All's well: he knows me not. Sir, your civility is obliging to a Stranger, and may befriend me, in the acquaintance of our fellow-Lodgers.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Hold you there, Sir: I must first understand you a little better; and yet, methinks, you shou'd be true to love.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Drinking, and Wenching, are but slips of Youth: I had those good qualities from my Father.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Thou, Boy! Aha, Boy! a true Trojan, I warrant thee!
Well, I say no more; but you are lighted into such a Family, such food for concupiscence, such Bona-Roba's!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: One I know indeed; a Wife: but Bona Roba's say you.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I say, Bona Roba's, in the Plural Number.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, what a Turk Mahomet shall I be! No, I will not make my self drunk, with the conceit of so much joy: the Fortunes too great for mortal man; and I a poor unworthy sinner.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Wou'd I lye to my Friend? Am I a Man? am I a Christian? there is that Wife you mention'd, a delicate little wheedling Devil, with such an appearance of simplicity; and with that, she does undermine, so fool her conceited Husband, that he despises her!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Just ripe for horns: his destiny, like a Turks, is written in his forehead.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Peace, peace; thou art yet ordain'd for greater things. There's another too, a kept Mistress, a brave Strapping Jade, a two-handed Whore!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A kept Mistress too! my bowels yearn to her already: She's certain prize.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: But this Lady is so Termagant an Empress! and he so submissive, so tame, so led a Keeper, and as proud of his Slavery, as a French man: I am confident he dares not find her false, for fear of a quarrel with her; because he is sure to be at the charges of the War; She knows he cannot live without her, and therefore seeks occasions of falling out to make him purchase peace. I believe she's now aiming at a settlement.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Might not I ask you one civil question? How pass you your time in this Noble Family? for I find you are a Lover of the Game, and shou'd be loth to hunt in your Purliews.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I must first tell you something of my condition: I am here a Friend to all of 'em; I am their Fac totum, do all their business; for, not to boast, Sir, I am a man of general acquaintance: there's no News in Town, either Foreign or Domestick, but I have it first; no Mortgage of Lands, no sale of Houses, but I have a finger in 'em.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then, I suppose, you are a gainer by your pains.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: No, I do all gratis, and am most commonly a loser; only a Buck sometimes from this good Lord, or that good Lady in the Country: and I eat it not alone, I must have company.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pray, what company do you invite?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Peace, peace, I am coming to you: Why, you must know I am tender-natur'd; and if any unhappy difference have arisen betwixt a Mistress and her Gallant, then I strike in to do good offices betwixt 'em; and, at my own proper charges, conclude the quarrel with a reconciling Supper.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I find the Ladies of Pleasure are beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, I love the poor little Devils. I am indeed a Father to 'em, and so they call me: I give 'em my Counsel, and assist 'em with my Purse. I cannot see a pretty Sinner hurri'd to Prison by the Land-Pyrats, but Nature works, and I must Bail her: or want a Supper, but I have a couple of cram'd Chickens, a Cream Tart, and a Bottle of Wine to offer her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sure you expect some kindness in return.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Faith, not much: Nature in me is at low water-mark; my Body's a Jade, and tires under me, yet I love to smuggle still in a Corner; pat 'em down, and pur over 'em; but, after that, I can do 'em little harm.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then I'm acquainted with your business: you wou'd be a kind of Deputy-Fumbler under me.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: You have me right. Be you the Lyon, to devour the Prey, I am your Jack-Call, to provide it for you: there will be a Bone for me to pick.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Your Humility becomes your Age. For my part, I am vigorous, and throw at all.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: As right as if I had begot thee! Wilt thou give me leave to call thee Son?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Ha, mad Son!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mad Daddy!

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Your man told me, you were just return'd from Travel: what Parts have you last visited?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I came from France.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Then, perhaps, you may have known an ungracious Boy of mine there.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Like enough: pray, what's his name?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I must confess I do know the Gentleman; satisfie your self, he's in health, and upon his return.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: That's some comfort: But, I hear, a very Rogue, a lewd young Fellow.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The worst I know of him is, that he loves a Wench; and that good quality he has not stoln.

div.stage: Musick at the Balcony over head: Mrs. Tricksy and Judith appear.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: 'Tis at my Daughter Tricksy's Lodging, the kept Mistress I told you of, the Lass of Mettle: but for all she carries it so high, I know her Pedigree; her Mother's a Semstress in Dog and Bitch Yard, and was, in her Youth, as right as she is.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then she's a two-pil'd Punk, a Punk of two Descents.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: And her Father, the famous Cobler, who taught Walsingham to the Black-birds. How stand thy affections to her, thou lusty Rogue?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: All o'fire: a most urging Creature!

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Peace! they are beginning.

l.hi: 'GAinst Keepers we petition,
Who wou'd inclose the Common:
'Tis enough to raise Sedition
In the free-born subject Woman.
Because for his gold
I my body have sold,
He thinks I'm a Slave for my life;
He rants, domineers,
He swaggers and swears,
And wou'd keep me as bare as his Wife.
'Tis honest and fair,
That a Feast I prepare;
But when his dull appetite's o're,
I'le treat with the rest
Some welcomer Ghost,
For the Reck'ning was paid me before.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A Song against Keepers! this makes well for us lusty Lovers.

sp.speaker: Tricksy.
sp.p: (Above) Father, Father Aldo!

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Daughter Tricksy, are you there Child? your Friends at Barnet are all well, and your dear Master Limberham, that Noble Hephestion, is returning with 'em.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And you are come upon the Spur before, to acquaint me with the news.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Well, thou art the happiest Rogue in a kind Keeper! He drank thy health five times, supernaculum, to my Son Brain-sick; and dipt my Daughter Pleasance's little finger, to make it go down more glibly: And, before George, I grew tory rory, as they say, and strain'd a Brimmer through the Lilly-white Smock, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You will never leave these fumbling tricks, Father, till you are taken upon suspition of Manhood, and have a Bastard laid at your Door: I am sure you wou'd own it for your Credit.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, I shou'd not see it starve for the Mothers sake: for, if she were a Punk, she was good-natur'd, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) Well, if ever Son was blest with a hopeful Father, I am.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Who's that Gentleman with you?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: A young Monsieur return'd from travel; a lusty young Rogue; a true-mill'd Whoremaster, with the right Stamp. He's a Fellow-lodger, incorporate in our Society: for whose sake he came hither, let him tell you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) Are you gloting already? then there's hopes, I'saith.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You seem to know him, Father.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Know him! from his Cradle—What's your name?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Woodall of Woodall; I knew his Father; we were Contemporaries, and Fellow-Wenchers in our Youth.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) My honest Father stumbles into truth, in spight of lying.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I was just coming down to the Garden-house before you came.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I'm sorry I cannot stay to present my Son Woodall to you; but I have set you together, that's enough for me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Alone) 'Twas my study to avoid my Father, and I have run full into his mouth; and yet I have a strong hank upon him too, for I am private to as many of his Vertues, as he is of mine. After all, if I had an ounce of discretion left, I shou'd pursue this business no farther: but two fine Women in a House! Well, 'tis resolv'd, come what will on't, thou art answerable for all my sins, old Aldo.—
sp.stage: Enter Tricksy with a Box of Essences.
sp.p: Here she comes, this Heir-Apparent of a Semstress, and a Cobler! and yet, as she's adorn'd, she looks like any Princess of the Blood.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Aside) What a difference there is between this Gentleman, and my feeble Keeper, Mr. Limberham! He's to my wish, if he wou'd but make the least advances to me. Father Aldo tells me, Sir, you're a Traveller: what Adventures have you had in Foreign Countries?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I have no Adventures of my own can deserve your Curiosity; but, now I think on't, I can tell you one that hapned to a French Cavalier, a Friend of mine, at Tripoli.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No Wars, I beseech you: I am so weary of Father Aldo's Lorrain and Crequy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then this is as you wou'd desire it, a Love-Adventure. This French Gentleman was made a Slave to the Dye of Tripoli; by his good qualities gain'd his Masters favour; and after, by corrupting an Eunuch, was brought into the Seraglio privately, to see the Dye's Mistress.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: This is somewhat; proceed, sweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: He was so much amaz'd, when he first beheld her, leaning over a Balcone, that he scarcely dar'd to lift his eyes, or speak to her.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Aside) I find him now. But what follow'd of this dumb Interview?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The Nymph was gracious, and came down to him; but with so Goddess-like a presence, that the poor Gentleman was Thunder-struck again.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: That savour'd little of the Monsitur's Gallantry, especially when the Lady gave him incouragement.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The Gentleman was not so dull, but he understood the favour, and was presuming enough to try if she were Mortal: He advanc'd with more assurance, and took her fair bands: Was he not too bold, Madam? and wou'd not you have drawn back yours, had you been in the Sultana's place?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: If the Sultana lik'd him well enough to come down into the Garden to him. I suppose she came not thither to gather Nosegays.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Give me leave, Madam, to thank you, in my Friends behalf, for your favourable judgment.

He kiss'd her hand with an exceeding Transport; and finding that she prest his at the same instant, he proceeded with a greater eagerness to her lips: But, Madam, the Story wou'd be without life, unless you give me leave to act the Circumstances.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, I'll swear you are the most Natural Historian!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But now, Madam, my heart beats with joy, when I come to tell you the sweetest part of his Adventure: Opportunity was favourable, and Love was on his side; he told her, the Chamber was more private, and a fitter Scene for Pleasure. Then, looking on her. Eyes, he found 'em languishing; he saw her Cheeks blushing, and heard her Voice faultring in a half denial: he seiz'd her hand with an Amorous Extasie, and—.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you act your Part too far. Your Friend was unconscionable, if he desir'd more favours at the first Interview.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: He both desir'd, and obtain'd 'em, Madam, and so will—.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Heav'ns! I hear Mr. Limberham's voice: he's return'd from Barnet.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'll avoid him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: That's impossible; he'll meet you. Let me think a moment: Mrs. Saintly is abroad, and cannot discover you: Have any of the Servants seen you?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Then you shall pass for my Italian Merchant of Essences; Here's a little Box of 'em just ready.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But I speak no Italian, only a few broken scraps which I pick'd up from Scaramouch and Harlequin at Paris.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You must venture that: when we are rid of Limberham, 'tis but slipping into your Chamber, throwing off your black Periwig, and Riding Sute, and you come out an English-man. No more; he's here.

sp.speaker: Limberham.
sp.p: Why, how now, Pug? Nay, I must lay you over the Lips, to take hansel of 'em, for my welcom.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Putting him back) Foh! how you smell of Sweat, Dear!

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I have put my self into this same unsavoury heat, out of my violent affection to s • e thee, Fug, before George, as Father Aldo says; I cou'd not live without thee; thou art the purest Bed-fellow, though I say it, that I did nothing but dream of thee all night; and then I was so troublesome to Father Aido (for you must know, he and I were lodg'd together) that, in my Conscience, I did so kiss him, and so hug him in my sleep!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I dare be sworn 'twas in your sleep; for, when you are waking, you are the most honest, quiet Bed-fellow, that ever lay by woman.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Well, Pug, all shall be amended; I am come home on purpose to pay old Debts. But who is that same Fellow there? what makes he in our Territories?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You Auph you, do you not perceive it is the Italian Seignior, who is come to sell me Essences?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Is this the Seignior? I warrant you, 'tis he the Lampoon was made on.

div.stage: Sings the Tune of Seignior, and ends with Ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Prythee leave thy foppery, that we may have done with him. He asks an unreasonable price, and we cannot agree. Here, Seignior, take your Trinkets, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (taking the Box) A Dio, Seigniora.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Hold, pray stay a little, Seignior; a thing is come into my head o'th' sudden.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What wou'd you have, you eternal Sot? the Man's in haste.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: But why shou'd you be in your Frumps, Fug, when I design only to oblige you? I must present you with this Box of Essences; nothing can be too dear for thee.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Pray let him go, he understands no English.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Then how cou'd you drive a Bargain with him, Pug?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why, by Signs, you Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Very good! Then I'll first pull him by the Sleeve, that's a Sign to stay. Look you, Mr. Seignior, I wou'd make a Present of your Essences to this Lady; for I find I cannot speak too plain to you, because you understand no English. Be not you refractory now, but take ready Money: that's a Rule.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: This is a very dull Fellow! he says, he does not intend English. How much shall I offer him, Pug?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: If you will Present me, I have bidden him ten Guineys.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: And, before George, you bid him fair. Look you, Mr. Seignior, I will give you all these: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Do you see, Seignior?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Lo' you there, Pug, he does see. Here, will you take me at my word?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: A poco, a poco! why, a Pox o' you too, and you go to that. Stay, now I think on't, I can tickle him up with French; he'll understand that sure. Mounsieur, voulez vous prendre ces dix Guinnees, pour ces Essences? mon foy c'est assez.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Chi vala, Amici: ho di Casa! Taratapa, Taratapa, eus, maou, meau!— (To her.) I am at the end of my Italian, what will beome of me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (To him) Speak any thing, and make it pass for Italian; but be sure you take his Money.

p.hi: Seignier, jo non canno takare ten Guinneo, possibilmentè; 'tis to my losso.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: That is, Pug, he cannot possibly take ten Guineys, 'tis to his loss: now I understand him; this is almost English.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: English! away, you Fop! 'tis a kind of Lingua Franca, as I have heard the Merchants call it; a certain compound Language, made up of all Tongues that passes through the Levant.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: This Lingua, what you call it, is the most ratest Language, I understand it as well as if it were English; you shall see me answer him: Seignioro, stay a little, and consider wello, ten Guinnio is monyo, a very considerablo summo.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come, you shall make it twelve, and he shall take it for my sake.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Then, Seignioro, for Pugsakio, addo two moro: je vous donne bon advise: prenez vistement: prenez me a mon mot.

p.hi: Jo losere molto: ma per gagnare it vestro costumo, datemi hansello.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: There is both hansello and Guinnio; tako, tako; and so Goodmorrow.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Good-morrow, Seignior, I like your Spirits very well; pray let me have all your Essence you can spare.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Come, Puggio, and let us retire in secreto, like Lovers, into our Chambro; for I grow impatiento. — Bon Matin, Mounsieur, bon Matin & bon jour.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well, get thee gone, Squire Limberhamo, for the easiest Fool I ever knew, next my Naunt of Fairies in the Alchemist. I have escap'd, thanks to my Mistresses Lingua Franca: I'll steal to my Chamber, shift my Periwig, and Cloaths; and then, with the help of resty Gervase, concert the business of the next Campaign. My Father sticks in my Stomach still; but I am resolv'd to be Woodall with him, and Aldo with the Women.

div.head: ACT. II. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
HItherto, sweet Gervase, we have carri'd matters swimmingly: I have danc'd in a Net before my Father, almost Check-mated the Keeper, retir'd to my Chamber undiscover'd,
shifted my Mabit, and am come out an absolute Mounsieur to allure the Ladies. How sits my Chedreux?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O very finely! with the Locks comb'd down, like a Maremaids, on a Sign-post. Well, you think now your Father may live in the same house with you till Dooms-day, and never find you; or, when he has found you, he will be kind enough not to consider what a Property you have made of him. My Employment is at an end; you have got a better Pimp, thanks to your Filial Reverence.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prythee what shou'd a man do with such a Father, but use him thus? Besides, he does Journey-work under me; 'tis his humour to sumble, and my duty to provide for his old age.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Take my advice yet; down o' your Marrow-bones, and ask forgiveness; Espouse the Wife he has provided for you; lye by the side of a wholesom Woman, and procreate your own Progeny in the fear of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I have no vocation to it, Gervase: A man of Sense is not made for Marriage; 'tis a Game, which none but dull plodding Fellows can play at well; and 'tis as natural to them, as Crimp is to a Dutch-man.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Think on't however, Sir; Debauchery is upon its last Legs in England: witty men began the Fashion; and, now the Fops are got into't, 'tis time to leave it.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Son Woodall, thou vigorous young Rogue, I congratulate thy good Fortune; thy Man has told me the Adventure of the Italian Merchant.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well, they are now retir'd together, like Rinaldo and Armida, to private dalliance; but we shall find a time to separate their loves, and strike in betwixt 'em, Daddy: But I hear there's another Lady in the house, my Landladies fair Daughter; how came you to leave her out of your Catalogue?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: She's pretty, I confess, but most damnably honest; have a care of her, I warn you, for she's prying and malicious.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A tang of the Mother; but I love to graff on such a Crabtree; she may bear good fruit another year.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: No, no, avoid her: I warrant thee, young Alexander, I will provide thee more Worlds to conquer.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: (Aside) My old Master wou'd fain pass for Philip of Macedon, when he is little better than Sir Pandarus of Troy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If you get this Keeper out of doors, Father, and give me but an opportunity—

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Trust my diligence; I will smoak him out, as they do Bees, but I will make him leave his Honey-comb.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: (Aside). If I had a thousand Sons, none of the Race of the Gervases shou'd ever be educated by thee, thou vile old Satan.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Away Boy, fix thy Arms, and whet, like the lusty German Boys, before a Charge: he shall bolt immediately.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O, fear not the vigorous five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Hold, a word first: Thou said'st my Son was shortly to come over.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: So he told me.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Thou art my Bosom Friend.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: (Aside) Of an hours acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Be sure thou dost not discover my frailties to the young Scoundrel: 'twere enough to make the Boy my Master. I must keep up the Dignity of old Age with him.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Keep but your own counsel, Father; for what ever he knows, must come from you.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: The truth on't is, I sent for him over; partly to have marri'd him, and partly because his villanous Bills came so thick upon me, that I grew weary of the charge.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: He spar'd for nothing; he laid it on, Sir, as I have heard.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Peace, you lying Rogue, believe me, Sir, bating his necessary expences of Women, which I know you wou'd not have him want: in all things else, he was the best manager of your allowance; and, tho I say it,—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: (Aside.) That shou'd not say it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The most hopeful young Gentleman in Paris.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Report speaks otherwise. And before George, I shall read him a Worm-wood Lecture, when I see him. But hark, I hear the door unlock; the Lovers are coming out: I'll stay here, to wheedle him abroad; but you must vanish.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Like Night and the Moon, in the Maids Tragedy: I into Myst; you into Day.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Nay, but dear sweet honey Pug, forgive me but this. once: it may be any man's case, when his desires are too vehement.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Let me alone; I care not.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: But then thou wilt not love me, Pug.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: How now Son Limberham? there's no quarrel towards, I hope!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You had best tell now, and make your self rediculous!

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: She's in Passion: Pray do you moderate this matter, Father Aldo.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
Father Aldo! I wonder you are not asham'd to call him
so! you may be his Father, if the truth were known.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, I smell a Rat. Son Limberham: I doubt, I doubt here has been some great omission in Love affairs.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: I think all the Stars in Heav'n have conspired my ruin. I'll look in my Asmanack—As I hope for mercy 'tis cross day now.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hang your pitiful excuses. 'Tis well known what offers I have had, and what fortunes I might have made with others, like a fool as I was, to throw away my youth and Beauty upon you. I could have had a young handsome Lord, that offer'd me my Coach and six; besides many a good Knight and Gentleman, that wou'd have parted with their own Ladies, and have setled half they had upon me.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: I, you said so.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I said so, Sir! who am I? is not my word as good as yours?

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: As mine, Gentlewoman? tho I say it, my word will go for thousands.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The more shame for you, that you have done no more for me: But I am resolv'd I'll not lose my time with you; I'll part.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Do, who cares? Go to Dog and Bitch yard, and help your Mother to make Footmens Shirts.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I defy you, Slanderer, I defy you.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Nay, dear Daughter!

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: I defy her too.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Nay, good Son!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Let me alone: I'll have him cudgel'd, by my Footman.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Bless us! what's here to do? My Neighbours will think I keep a Nest of unclean Birds here.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: You had best preach now, and make her house be thought a Baudy-house!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, no: while you are in't, you'l secure it from that scandal. Hark hither, Mrs. Saintly.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Do, tell, tell, no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Who wou'd have imagin'd you had been such a kind of man, Mr. Limberham! O Heav'n, O Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: So, Now you have spit your Venom, and the Storm's over.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: (crying.) That I shou'd ever live to see this day!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: To show I can live honest, in spight of all mankind, I'll go into a Nunnery, and that's my resolution.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Don't hinder her, good Father Aldo; I'm sure she'l come back from France, before she gets half way o're to Calais.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Nay, but Son Limberham, this must not be: a word in private. You'l never get such another Woman, for Love nor Money. Do but look upon her; she's a Mistriss for an Emperor.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Let her be a Mistress for a Pope, like a Whore of Babylon, as she is.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Wou'd I were worthy to be a young man, for her sake: she shou'd eat Pearl, if she wou'd have 'em.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: She can digest 'em, and Gold too. Let me tell you Father Aldo, she has the Stomach of an Estrich.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Daughter Tricksy, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I'll hear nothing: I am for a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I never saw a Woman, before you, but first or last she wou'd be brought to Reason. Hark you Child, you'l scarcely find so kind a keeper: What if he has some impediment one way? every body is not a Hercules. You shall have my Son VVoodal, to supply his wants; but as long as he maintains you, be rul'd by him that bears the purse.

l.hi: I my own Jaylour was; my only Foe,
VVho did my liberty forego;
I was a Pris'ner, cause I wou'd be so.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Why, look you now, Son Limberham, is this a Song to be sung at such a time, when I am labouring your reconcilement? Come Daughter Tricksy, you must be rul'd; I'll be the Peace-maker.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, I'm just going.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: The Devil take me, if I call you back.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And his Dam take me, if I return, except you do.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: So, now you'l part, for a meer Punctilio! Turn to him, Daughter: speak to her, Son. Why shou'd you be so refractory both, to bring my gray hairs with sorrow to the grave?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I'll not be forsworn, I swore first.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Thou art a forsworn man however; for thou swor'st to love me eternally.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Yes, I was such a fool, to swear so.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: And will you have that dreadful oath ly gnawing on your Conscience?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Let him be damn'd; and so farewel for ever.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Pug!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Did you call, Mr. Limberham.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: It may be, I; it may be, No.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, I am going to the Nunnery: but to show I am in charity, I'll pray for you.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Pray for him! fy, Daughter, fy; is that an answer for a Christian?

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: What did Pug say? will she pray for me? Well, to show I am in Charity, she shall not pray for me. Come back, Pug. But did I ever think thou coud'st have been so unkind to have parted with me?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Look you, Daughter, see how nature works in him!

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: I'll settle two hundred a year upon thee, because thou said'st thou wou'dst pray for me.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, Son Limberham, you'l spoil all, if you under-bid so. Come, down with your dust, man: what, show a base mind, when a fair Lady's in question!

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Well, if I must give three hundred.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, 'tis no matter; my thoughts are on a better place.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Come, there's no better place, than little London. You sha'not part for a Trifle. What, Son Limberham? four hundred a year's a square sum, and you shall give it.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: 'Tis a round Sum indeed; I wish a three-corner'd sum wou'd have serv'd her turn. Why shou'd you be so pervicatious now, Pug? Pray take three hundred.—Nay, rather than part, Pug, it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: It shall be so, it shall be so: come, now buss, and seal the bargain.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (kissing him.) You see what a good-natur'd fool I am, Mr. Limberham, to come back into a wicked World, for love of you. You'l see the Writings drawn, Father?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I; and pay the Lawyer too. Why, this is as it shou'd be! I'll be at the charge of the reconciling Supper— (To her aside.) Daughter, my Son VVoodall is waiting for you.—Come away, Son Limberham, to the Temple.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: With all my heart, while she's in a good humor: it wou'd cost me another hundred, if I shou'd stay till Pug were in wrath again. Adieu, sweet Pug.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: That he shou'd be so silly to imagine I wou'd go into a Nunnery! 'tis likely; I have much Nuns Flesh about me! But here comes my Gentleman.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p:
Now the Wife's return'd, and the Daughter too, and I have seen 'em both, and am more distracted than before: I wou'd enjoy all, and have not yet determin'd with which I shou'd begin. 'Tis but a kind of Clergy-covetousness in me, to desire so many; if I
stand gaping after Pluralities, one of 'em is in danger to be made a Sine cure.— (Sees her.) O, Fortune has determin'd for me. 'Tis just, here, as it is in the World; the Mistress will be serv'd before the Wife.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: How now, Sir? are you rehearsing your Lingua Franca by your self, that you walk so pensively?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: No faith, Madam, I was thinking of the fair Lady, who at parting bespoke so cunningly of me all my Essences.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But there are other Beauties in the house, and I shou'd be impatient of a Rival: for I am apt to be partial to my self, and think I deserve to be prefer'd before 'em.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Your Beauty will allow of no competition; And I am sure my love cou'd make none.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, you have seen Mrs. Brainsick. she's a Beauty.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You mean, I suppose, the peaking Creature, the Marry'd VVoman, with a sideling look, as if one Cheek carry'd more byass than the other?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, and with a high Nose, as visible as a land-mark.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: With one cheek blew, the other red: just like the covering of Lambeth Palace.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nay, but her legs, if you cou'd see 'em—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: She was so foolish to wear short Petticoats, and show 'em. They are pillars, gross enough to support a larger building; of the Tuscan order, by my troth.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And her little, head, upon that long neck, shows like a Traitor's scull upon a pole. Then, for her wit.—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: She can have none: there's not room enough for a Thought to play in.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I think indeed I may safely trust you with such Charms; and you have pleas'd me with your description of her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I wish you wou'd give me leave to please you better, but you transact as gravely with me as a Spaniard; and are losing Love, as he does Flanders: you consider, and demur, when the Monarch is up in Arms, and at your Gates.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But to yield upon the first Summons, e're you have laid a formal Siege—
To morrow may prove a luckier day to you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Believe me, Madam, Lovers are not to trust to morrow: Love may die upon our hands, or opportunity be wanting; 'tis best securing the present hour.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, Love's like Fruit; it must have time to ripen on the Tree; if it be green gather'd, 'twill but wither afterwards.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Rather 'tis like Gun-powder; that which fires quickest, is commonly the strongest.—By this burning kiss—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
You Lovers are such froward Children, ever crying for the
Breast; and, when you have once had it, fall fast asleep in the Nurses Arms.—And with what face shou'd I look upon my Keeper after it?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: With the same face that all Mistresses look upon theirs. Come, come.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But my Reputation!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, that's no Argument, if I shou'd be so base to tell; for Women get good fortunes now-a-daies, by losing their Credit, as a cunning Citizen does by Breaking.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But I'm so shame-fac'd! Well, I'll go in, and hide my Blushes.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'll not be long after you; for I think I have hidden my Blushes where I shall never find 'em.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: As I live, Mr. Limberham, and Father Aldo, are just return'd; I saw 'em entring. My Settlement will miscarry, if you are found here, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Go you into your Bed-chamber, and leave me to my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: That you shou'd be so dull! their suspition will be as strong still; for what shou'd you make here?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The curse on't is too, I bid my Man tell the Family I was gone abroad; so that if I am seen, you are infallibly discover'd.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hark, I hear 'em! Here's a Chest which I borrow'd of Mrs. Pleasance; get quickly into it, and I will lock you up: there's nothing in't, but Cloaths of Limberham's, and a Box of Writings.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I shall be smother'd.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Make haste, for Heav'n sake; they'l quickly be gone, and then—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That Then, will make a man venture any thing.

div.stage: He goes in, and she locks the Chest.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Dost thou not wonder, to see me come again so quickly, Pug?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, I am prepar'd for any foolish freak of yours: I knew you wou'd have a qualm, when you came to settlement.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Your settlement depends most absolutely on that Chest.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Father Aldo, a word with you, for Heav'n sake.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: No, no, I'll not whisper: do not stand in your own light, but produce the Keys, Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Be not musty, my pretty S. Peter, but produce the Keys; I must have the Writings out that concern thy Settlement.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Now I see you are so reasonable, I'll show you I dare trust your honesty; the Settlement shall be defer'd till another day.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: No deferring, in these cases, Daughter.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But I have lost the Keys.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: That's a jest! let me feel in thy Pocket, for I must oblige thee.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You shall feel no where: I have felt already, and am sure they are lost.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: But feel again, the Lawyer stays.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, to satisfie you, I will feel. — They are not here.— Nor here neither.

div.stage: She pulls out her Handkerchief, and the Keys drop after it: Limberham takes 'em up.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Look you now, Pug! who's in the right? Well, thou art born to be a lucky Pug, in spight of thy self.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Aside) O, I am ruin'd! — One word, I beseech you, Father Aldo.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Not a syllable: what's the Devil in you, Daughter? Open Son, open.

sp.speaker: Trick
sp.p: (Aloud). It shall not be open'd; I will have my will, though I lose my Settlement: Wou'd I were within the Chost, I wou'd hold it down, to spight you: I say again, wou'd I were within the Chest, I wou'd hold it so fait, you shou'd not open it: the best on't is, there's good Inckle on the top of the in-side, if he have the wit to lay hold on't.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: (Going to open it) Before George, I think you have the Devil in a String, Pug; I cannot open it, for the Guts of me. Hictius Doctius! what's here to do? I believe, in my Conscience, Pug can Conjure: Marry, God bless us all good Christians.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Push hard, Son.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I cannot push; I was never good at pushing: when I push, I think the Devil pushe too. Well, I must let it alone, for I am a Fumbler. Here, take the Keys, Pug.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Aside) Then all's safe again.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Madam, Mrs. Pleasance has sent for the Chest you borrow'd of her: she has present occasion for it; and has desir'd us to carry it away.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Well, that's but reason: if sh • must have it, she must have it.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Tell her, it shall be return'd some time to day; at present we must crave her pardon, because we have some Writings in it, which must first be taken out, when we can open it.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, that's but reason too: then she must not have it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Let me come to't; I'll break it open, and you may take out your Writings.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: That's true: 'tis but reasonable it shou'd be broken open.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Then I may be bound to make good the loss.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: 'Tis unreasonable it shou'd be broken open.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, Gervase and I will carry it away; and a Smith shall be sent for to my Daughter Pleasance's Chamber, to open it without damage.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Why, who says against it? Let it be carri'd; I'm all for Reason.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hold; I say it shall not stir.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: What? every one must have their own: Fiat Justitia aut ruat Mundus.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I fiat Justitia, Pug: she must have her own; for Justitia is Latin for Justice.

div.stage: Aldo and Gervase lift at it.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I think the Devil's in't.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: There's somewhat bounces, like him, in't. 'Tis plaguy heavy; but we'll take t'other heave.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Taking hold of the Chest) Then you shall carry me too. Help, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, I think all Hell's broke loose among you. What, a Schism in my Family! Does this become the Purity of my House? What will the ungodly say?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: No matter for the ungodly; this is all among our selves: for, look you, the business is this, Mrs. Pleasance has sent for this same Business here, which she lent to Pug; now Pug has some private Businesses within this Business, which she wou'd take out first, and the Business will not be open'd: and this makes all the Business.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, I am rais'd up for a Judge amongst you; and I say—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I'll have no Judge: it shall not go.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Why Son, why Daughter, why Mrs. Saintly; are you all mad? Hear me, I am sober, I am discreet; let a Smith be sent for hither, let him break open the Chest; let the things contained be taken out, and the thing containing be restor'd.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Now hear me too, for I am sober and discreet; Father Aldo is an Oracle: it shall be so.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, to show I am reasonable, I am content, Mr. Gervase and I will fetch an Instrument from the next Smith; in the mean time, let the Chest remain where it now stands, and let every one depart the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: That no violence be offer'd to the Person of the Chest, in Pug's absence.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Then this matter is compos'd.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Aside) Now I shall have leisure to instruct his Man, and set him free, without discovery. Come, Mr. Cervase.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: There is a certain motion put into my mind, and it is of good; I have Keys here, which a precious Brother, a devout Blacksmith, made me; and which will open any Lock of the same bore: verily, it can be no sin to unlock this Chest therewith, and take from thence the spoils of the ungodly. I will satisfie my Conscience, by giving part thereof to the Hungry, and the Needy; some to our Pastor, that he may prove it lawful; and some I will sanctifie to my own use.

div.stage: She unlocks the Chest, and Woodall starts up.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let me imbrace you, my dear Deliverer!
Bless us! is it you, Mrs. Saintly?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: (Shrieking) Heav'n, of his mercy! Stop Thief, stop Thief.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What will become of me now?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: According to thy wickedness, shall it be done unto thee. Have I discover'd thy back-slidings, thou unfaithful man! thy Treachery to me shall be rewarded, verily; for I will testifie against thee.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, since you are so revengeful, you shall suffer your part of the disgrace; if you testifie against me for Adultery, I shall testifie against you for Theft: there's an Eighth for your Seventh.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, they are approaching: return to my imbraces, and it shall be forgiven thee.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Thank you, for your own sake: Hark! they are coming! cry Thief again, and help to save all yet.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Stop Thief, stop Thief.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Thank you, for your own sake; but I fear 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Entring) The Chest open, and Woodall discover'd, I am ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Enter Limb.
sp.p: Why all this shrieking, Mrs. Saintly?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Rushing him down) Stop Thief, stop Thief, stop Thief! cry you mercy, Gentleman, if I have hurt you.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: (Rising) 'Tis a fine time to cry a man mercy, when you have beaten his wind out of his body.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: As I watched the Chest, behold a Vision rushed out of it, on the sudden; and I lifted up my voice, and shriek'd.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: A Vision, Landlady; what, have we Gog and Magog in our Chamber?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A Thief, I warrant you, who had gotten into the Chest.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Most certainly a Thief: for hearing my Landlady cry out, I flew from my Chamber to her help, and met him running down
stairs; and then he turn'd back to the Balcone, and lept into the Street.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: I thought indeed that something held down the Chest, when I would have open'd it: — But my VVritings are there still; that's one comfort! — Oh Seignioro, are you here!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Do you speak to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: This is Mr. Woodall, your new fellow-Lodger.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, Sir; I durst have sworn you cou'd have spoken Lingua Franca. — I thought in my Conscience, Pug, this had been thy Italian Merchanto.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sir, I see you mistake me for some other: I shou'd be happy to be better known to you.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Sir, I beg your pardon with all my hearto. Before George, I was caught again there! But you are so very like a paltry Fellow, who came to sell Pug Essences this morning, that one wou'd swear those Eyes, and that Nose and Mouth, belong'd to that Rascal.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You must pardon me, Sir, if I don't much relish the close of your Complement.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Their Eyes are nothing like: (you'll have a quarrel.)

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Not very like, I confess.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Their Nose and Mouth are quite different.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: As Pug says, they are quite different indeed: but I durst have sworn it had been he; and therefore once again, I demand your pardone.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come, let us go down; by this time Gervase has brought the Smith; and then Mrs. Pleasance may have her Chest. Please you, Sir, to bear us company.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: At your service, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Pray lead the way, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis against my will, Sir: but I must leave you in possession.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Pleasance.
sp.p: NEver fear it, I'll be a Spy upon his actions: he shall neither whisper nor glote on either of 'em, but I'll ring him such a Peal!

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Above all things, have a care of him your self; for surely there is Witchcraft betwixt his Lips: he is a Wolf within the Sheepfold; and therefore I will be earnest, that you may not fall.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
Why shou'd my Mother be so inquisitive about this Lodger?
I half suspect Old Eve her self has a mind to be nibling at the Pippin: he makes Love to one of 'em, I am confident; it may be to both; for methinks I shou'd have done so, if I had been a Man; but the damn'd Petticoats have perverted me to honesty, and therefore I have a grudge to him, for the Priviledge of his Sex. He shuns me too, and that vexes me; for though I wou'd deny him, I scorn he shou'd not think me worth a civil question.

div.stage: Re-enter Woodall, with Tricksy, Mrs. Brainsick, Judith, and Musick.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Come, your works, your works; they shall have the approbation of Mrs. Pleasance.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No more Apologies: give Judith the words; she sings at sight.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I'll try my skill.

div.head: A SONG from the ITALIAN.

l.hi: BY a dismal Cypress lying,

div.l: Damon cry'd, all pale and dying,

l.hi: Kind is Death that ends my pain,
But cruel She I lov'd in vain.
The Mossy Fountains
Murmure my trouble,
And hollow Mountains
My groans redouble:
Every Nymph mourns me,
Thus while I languish;
She only scorns me,
Who caus'd my anguish.
No Love returning me, but all hope denying;
By a dismal Cypress lying,

div.l: Like a Swan, so sung he dying:

l.hi: Kind is Death that ends my pain,
But cruel She I lov'd in vain.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: By these languishing Eyes, and those Simagres of yours, we are given to understand, Sir, you have a Mistress in this Company: Come, make a free discovery which of 'em your Poetry is to Charm; and put the other out of pain.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No doubt 'twas meant to Mrs. Brainsick.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: We Wives are despicable Creatures: we know it, Madam, when a Mistress is in presence.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why this Ceremony betwixt you? 'Tis a likely proper Fellow, and looks as he cou'd People a new Isle of Pines.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: 'Twere a work of Charity to convert a fair young Schismatick, like you, if 'twere but to gain you to a better Opinion of the Government.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: If I am not mistaken in you two, he has works of Charity enough upon his hands already; but 'tis a willing Soul, I'll warrant him, eager upon the Quarry, and as sharp as a Governour of Covent-Garden.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sure this is not the phrase of your Family: I thought to have found a sanctifi'd Sister; but I suspect now, Madam, that if your Mother kept a Pension in your Father's time, there might be some Gentleman-Lodger in the house; for I humbly conceive, you are of the half-strain at least.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: For all the rudeness of your Language, I am resolv'd to know upon what Voyage you are bound: you Privateer of Love, you Argier's Man, that Cruse up and down for prize in the Streights Mouth; which of the Vessels wou'd you snap now?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: We are both under safe Convoy, Madam: a Lover, and a Husband.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Nay, for your part, you are notably guarded, I confess; but Keepers have their Rooks, as well as Gamesters: But they only venture under 'em, till they pick up a Sum, and then push for themselves.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) A Plague of her suspitions; they'l ruine me on that side.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: So; let but little Minx go proud, and the Dogs in Covent-Garden have her in the wind immediately: all pursue the Scent.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Not to a Boarding-house, I hope!

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: If they were wise, they wou'd rather go to a Brothel-house; for there most Mistresses have left behind 'em their Maiden-heads, of blessed memory: and those which wou'd not go off in that Market, are carri'd about by Bauds, and sold at doors, like stale Flesh in Baskets. Then, for your honesty, or justness, as you call it, to your Keepers, your kept Mistress is originally a Punk; and let the Cat be chang'd into a Lady never so formally, she still retains her natural property of Mousing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: You are very sharp upon the Mistresses; but I hope you'l spare the Wives.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, as much as your Husbands do, after the first Month of Marriage; but you requite their negligence in Houshold-duties, by making them Husbands of the first Head, e're the year be over.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) She has me there too!

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And, as for you, young Gallant,

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hold, I beseech you, a Truce for me.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
In troth I pity you, for you have undertaken a most difficult Task, to cozen two Women, who are no Babies in their Art, if you
bring it about, you perform as much as he that cheated the very Lottery.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ladies, I am sorry this shou'd happen to you for my sake: she's in a raging Fit, you see; 'tis best withdrawing, till the Spirit of Prophecy has left her.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I'll take shelter in my Chamber,—whither, I hope, he'll have the grace to follow me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: And, now I think on't, I have some Letters to dispatch.

div.stage: Ex. Trick. and Mrs. Brain severally.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Now, good John among the Maids, how mean you to bestow your time? Away, to your Study I advise you, invoke your Muses, and make Madrigals upon absence.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I wou'd go to China, or Japan, to be rid of that impetuous Clack of yours: Farewel, thou Legion of Tongues in one Woman.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Will you not stay, Sir? it may be I have a little business with you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, the second part of the same Tune! Strike by your self, sweet Larm; you're true Bell-mettal, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: This spightfulness of mine will be my ruine: To rail them off, was well enough; but to talk him away too! O Tongue, Tongue! thou wert given for a Curse to all our Sex!

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Madam, your Mother wou'd speak with you.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I will not come: I'm mad I think: I come immediately. Well, I'll go in, and vent my passion, by railing at them, and him too.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: You may enter in safety, Sir, the Enemy's march'd off.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nothing, but the love I bear thy Mistress, cou'd keep me in the house with such a Fury. VVhen will the bright Nymph appear?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Immediately: I hear her coming.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That I cou'd find her coming, Mrs. Judith!
You have made me languish in expectation, Madam. VVas it nothing, do you think, to be so near a happiness, with violent desires, and to be delay'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Is it nothing, do you think, for a VVoman of Honour, to overcome the tyes of Vertue and Reputation; to do that for you, which I thought I shou'd never have ventur'd for the sake of any man?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But, my comfort is, that Love has overcom. Your Honour is, in other words, but your good Repute; and 'tis my part to take care of that: for the Fountain of a Womans Honour is in the Lover, as that of the Subject is in the King.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: You had concluded well, if you had been my Husband: you know where our subjection lies.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But cannot I be yours, without a Priest? They were cunning people, doubtless, who began that Trade; to have a double Hank upon us, for two Worlds: that no pleasure here, or hereafter shou'd be had, without a Bribe to them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Well, I'm resolv'd, I'll read, against the next time I see you; for, the truth is, I am not very well prepar'd with Arguments for Marriage; mean while, farewell.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I stand corrected; you have reason indeed to go, if I can use my time no better: We'll withdraw, if you please, and dispute the rest within.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Perhaps, I meant not so.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I understand your meaning at your Eyes. You'll watch, Judith?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Nay, if that were all, I expect not my Husband till to morrow: The Truth is, he's so odly humour'd, that, if I were ill-inclin'd, it wou'd half justifie a Woman: He's such a kind of Man.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Or, if he be not, we'll make him such a kind of Man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: So Fantastical, so Musical, his talk all Rapture, and half Nonsence: Like a Clock out of order, set him a going, and he strikes eternally. Besides, he thinks me such a Fool, that I cou'd half resolve to revenge my self, in justification of my Wit.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Come, come, no half resolutions among Lovers; I'll hear no more of him, till I have reveng'd you fully. Go out, and watch, Judith.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Yet, I cou'd say, in my defence, that my Friends marryed me to him against my will.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then let us put your Friends too, into the Quarrel: it shall go hard, but I'll give you a Revenge for them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Can'st thou not speak? hast thou seen a Ghost?— As I live, she signs Horns! that must be for my Husband: He's return'd.

div.stage: Judith looks ghastly, and signs Horns.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I wou'd have told you so, if I cou'd have spoken for fear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p:
Hark, a knocking! what shall we do? [Knocking.] There's no dallying in this case: here you must not be found, that's
certain; but Judith hath a Chamber within mine; haste quickly thither; I'll secure the rest.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Follow me, Sir.

div.stage: Knocking again. She opens: Enter Brainsick.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: What's the matter, Gentlewoman? am I excluded from my own Fortress; and by the way of Barricado? Am I to dance Attendance at the Door, as if I were some base Plebeian Groom? I'll have you know, that when my Foot assaults, the Lightning and the Thunder are not so terrible as the strokes: Brasen Gates shall tremble, and Bolts of Adamant dismount from off their Hinges, to admit me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Who wou'd have thought that 'none Dear wou'd have come so soon? I was e'en lying down on my Bed, and dreaming of him: Tum a' me, and buss, poor Dear, piddee buss.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: I nauseat these foolish Feats of Love.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Nay, but why shou'd he be so fretful now? and knows I doat on him; to leave a poor Dear so long without him, and then come home in an angry humour! indeed I'll ky.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Prythee leave thy fulsom fondness; I have surfeited on Conjugal Embraces.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: I thought so; some light Huswife has bewitch'd him from me: I was a little Fool, so I was, to leave a Dear behind at Barnet, when I knew the Women wou'd run mad for him.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: I have a luscious Air forming, like a Pallas, in my Brain-pan; and now thou com'st a cross my fancy, to disturb the rich Idea's, with the yellow Jaundies of thy Jealousie. (Noise within.) Hark, what noise is that within, about Judith's Bed?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: I believe, Dear, she's making it.—Wou'd the Fool wou'd go.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Hark, again!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: (Aside.) I have a dismal apprehension in my head, that he's giving my Maid a cast of his Office, in my stead. O, how it stings me!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: I'll enter, and find the reason of this Tumult.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: (holding him.) Not for the World: there may be a Thief there; and shou'd I put 'none Dear in danger of his life?— What shall I do? betwixt the jealousie of my Love, and fear of this Fool, I am distracted: I must not venture 'em together, what e're comes on't. Why, Judith, I say! Come forth, Damsel.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (within.) The danger's over: I may come out safely.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: (within.) Are you mad? you sha' not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: (aside.) So, now I'm ruin'd unavoidably.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Who e're thou art, I have pronounc'd thy Doom; the dreadful Brainsick bares his brawny Arm in tearing terrour; kneeling Queens in vain shou'd beg thy being.—Sa, sa, there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: (aside.) Tho I believe he dares not venture in; yet I must not put it to the Tryal. Why Judith, come out, come out, Huswife.
What Villain have you hid within?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: O Lord, Madam, what shall I say?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: How shou'd I know what you shou'd say? Mr. Brainsick has heard a Man's Voice within; if you know what he makes there, confess the truth; I am almost dead with fear, and he stands shakeing.

sp.speaker: Brain.
