sp.p: Terrour, I! 'tis indignation shakes me. With this Sabre I'll slice him small as Atoms; he shall be doom'd by the Judge, and damn'd upon the Gibbet.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: (kneeling.) My Master's so out-ragious, sweet Madam, do you intercede for me, and I'll tell you all in private. (Whispers.) If I say it is a Thief, he'll call up help; I know not what o'th'sudden to invent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Let me alone.—And is this all? why wou'd you not confess it before, Judith? when you know I am an indulgent Mistress

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: What has she confess'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: A venial Love-Trespass, Dear: 'Tis a Sweet-heart of hers; one that is to marry her; and she was unwilling I shou'd know it, so she hid him in her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: What's the matter tro? what in Martial posture, Son Brainsick?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Pray, Father Aldo, do you beg my pardon of my Master: I have committed a Fault; I have hidden a Gentleman in my Chamber, who is to marry me without his Friends consent, and therefore came in private to me.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: That thou shou'dst think to keep this secret! why, I know it as well as he that made thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs Brain.
sp.p: (aside.) Heav'n be prais'd, for this Knower of all things: Now will he lye three or four rapping Voluntiers, rather than be thought ignorant in any thing.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Do you know his Friends, Father Aldo?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Know 'em! I think I do. His Mother was an Arch-Deacon's Daughter; as honest a Woman as ever broke Bread: She and I have been Cater-Cousins in our Youth; we have tumbled together between a pair of Sheets, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: An honest woman, and yet you two have tumbled together! those are inconsistent.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: No matter for that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: He blunders; I must help him. I warrant 'twas before Marriage, that you were so great.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, and so it was: for she had the prettiest black Mole upon her left Ancle, it does me good to think on't! His Father was Squire what d' you call him, of what d' you call 'em Shire. What think you, little Judith? do Iknow him now?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: I suppose you may be mistaken: my Servant's Father is a Knight of Hamshire.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I meant of Hamshire. But that I shou'd forget he was a Knight, when I got him Knighted at the King's coming in! Two fat Bucks, I am sure, he sent me.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: And what's his Name?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Nay, for that, you must excuse me: I must not disclose little Judith's secrets.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: All this while the poor Gentleman is left in pain: we must let him out in secret; for I believe the young Fellow is so bashful, he wou'd not willingly be seen.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: The best way will be, for Father Aldo to lend me the Key of his Door, which opens into my Chamber; and so I can convey him out.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: (Giving her a Key) Do so, Daughter. Not a word of my familiarity with his Mother, to prevent blood-shed betwixt us: but I have her Name down in my Almanack, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: What, kiss and tell, Father Aldo; kiss and tell!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: I'll go and pass an hour with Mrs. Tricksy.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: What, the lusty Lover Limberham!

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: O here's a Mounsieur, new come over, and a Fellow-lodger; I must endear you two to one another.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis my extream ambition to be better known to you: you come out of the Country I adore. And how does the dear Battist? I long for some of his new Compositions in the last Opera. A propo! I have had the most happy invention this morning, and a Tune trouling in my head; I rise immediately in my Night-Gown and Slippers, down I put the Notes slap dash, made words to 'em like Lightning: and I warrant you have 'em at the Circle in the Evening.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: All were compleat, Sir, if S. Andre wou'd make steps to 'em.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Nay, thanks to my Genius, that care's over: you shall see, you shall see. But first the Air.— (Sings.) Is't not very fine? Ha, Messeurs!

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: The close of it is the most ravishing I ever heard!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: I dwell not on your Commendations. What say you, Sir? (To Wood.) Is't not admirable? Do you enter into't?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Most delicate Cadence!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Gad, I think so, without vanity. Battist and I have but one Soul. But the close, the close! (Sings it thrice over.) I have words too upon the Air; but I am naturally so bashful!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Will you oblige me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: You might command me, Sir; for I sing too en Cavalier: but—

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: But you wou'd be intreated, and say, Nolo, nolo, nolo, three times, like any Bishop, when your mouth waters at the Diocess.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: I have no voice; but, since this Gentleman commands me, let the words commend themselves.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: But why, of all Names, wou'd you chuse a Phillis? There have been so many Phillis's in Songs, I thought there had not been another left, for Love or Money.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: If a man shou'd listen to a Fop! (Sings.)

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, I am on t'other side: I think, as good no Song, as no Phillis.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Yet again! — My Phillis— (Sings.)

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Pray, for my sake, let it be your Cloris.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: (Looking scornfully at him.) My Phillis— (Sings.)

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: You had as good call her your Succuba.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Morbleau! will you not give me leave? I am full of Phillis. (Sings.) My Phillis—

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, I confess, Phillis is a very pretty name.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Diable! Now I will not sing, to spight you. By the World, you are not worthy of it. Well, I have a Gentleman's Fortune, I have courage, and make no inconsiderable Figure in the World: yet I wou'd quit my pretensions to all these, rather than not be Author of this Sonnet, which your rudeness has irrevocably lost.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Some foolish French quelque chose, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Quelque chose! O ignorance, in supreme perfection! he means a kek shose.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Why, a kek shooes let it be then! And a kek shooes for your Song.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: I give to the Devil such a Judge: well, were I to be born again, I wou'd as soon be the Elephant, as a Wit; he's less a Monster in this Age of malice. I cou'd burn my Sonnet, out of rage.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: You may use your pleasure with your own.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: His Friends wou'd not suffer him: Virgil was not permitted to burn his Aeneids.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I'll not die ingrateful for your approbation: (Aside to Woodall) You see this Fellow? he's an Ass already; he has a handsome Mistress, and you shall make an Oxe of him, e're long.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Say no more, it shall be done.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Hark you, Mr. Woodall; this fool Brainsick grows insupporttable; he's a publick Nusance; but I scorn to set my wit against him: he has a pretty Wife: I say no more, but if you do not graff him—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A word to the wise: I shall consider him, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Pray do, Sir: consider him much.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Much is the word.—This fewd makes well for me.

sp.speaker: Brain to Wood.
sp.p: I'll give you the opportunity, and rid you of him.—Come away, little Limberham; you, and I, and Father Aldo, will take a turn together in the Square.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: We'll follow you immediately.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Yes, we'll come after you, Bully Brainsick: but I hope you will not draw upon us there.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: If you fear that, Bilbo shall be left behind.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, nay, leave but your Madrigal behind: draw not that upon us, and 'tis no matter for your Sword.

div.stage: Enter Tricksy, and Mrs. Brainsick, with a Note for each.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) Both together! either of 'em apart, had been my business: but I shall ne're play well at this Three-hand Game.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: O, Pug, how have you been passing of your time?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I have been looking over the last Present of Orange Gloves you made me; and methinks I do not like the scent.—O Lord, Mr. Woodall, did you bring those you wear from Paris?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mine are Roman, Madam.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The scent I love, of all the World. Pray let me see 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Nay, not both, good Mrs. Tricksy; for I love that scent as well as you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Pulling 'em off, and giving each one) I shall find two dozen more of Womens Gloves among my Trifles, if you please to accept 'em Ladies.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Look to't; we shall expect 'em.—Now to put in my Billet doux!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: So, now I have the opportunity to thrust in my Note.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Here, Sir, take your Glove again; the Perfume's too strong for me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Pray take the other to't; though I shou'd have kept it for a Pawn.

div.stage: Mrs. Brainsick's Note falls out, Lim. takes it up.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: What have we here? For Mr. Woodall.

sp.speaker: Both Women.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Mr. Limberham.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, Son Limberham, you shall read it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, but he must not.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He'll know my hand, and I am ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Oh, my misfortune! Mr. Woodall, will you suffer your secrets to be discover'd?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: It belongs to one of 'em, that's certain.—Mr. Limberham, I must desire you to restore this Letter; 'tis from my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The Devil's in him; will he confess?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This Paper was sent me from her this morning; and I was so fond of it, that I left it in my Glove: if one of the Ladies had found it there, I shou'd have been laugh'd at most unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: That's well come off!

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: My heart was at my mouth, for fear it had been Pug's— (Aside) There 'tis again.—Hold, hold; pray let me see't once more: A Mistress, said you?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Yes, a Mistress, Sir. I'll be his Voucher; he has a Mistress, and a fair one too.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Do you know it, Father Aldo?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Know it! I know the match is as good as made already: Old Woodall and I, are all one. You, Son, were sent for over on purpose; the Articles for her Joynture are all concluded, and a Friend of mine drew 'em.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, if Father Aldo knows it, I am satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: But how came you by this Letter, Son Woodall? let me examine you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Came by it! (Pox, he has non-plus'd me!) How do you say I came by it, Father Aldo?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Why, there's it, now. This morning I met your Mistresses Father, Mr. you know who—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mr. Who, Sir?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Nay, you shall excuse me for that; but we are intimate: his Name begins with some Vowel or Consonant, no matter which; well, her Father gave me this very Numerical Letter, superscrib'd, For Mr. Woodall.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Before George, and so it is.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Carry me this Letter, quoth he, to your Son Woodall; 'tis from my Daughter such a one, and then whisper'd me her Name.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let me see; I'll read it once again.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: What, are you not acquainted with the Contents of it?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O, your true Lover will read you over a Letter, from his Mistress, a thousand times.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I, two thousand, if he be in the humour.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Two thousand! then it must be hers. (Reads to himself.) Away, to your Chamber immediately, and I'll give my Fool the slip— (The Fool! that may be either the Keeper, or the Husband; but
commonly the Keeper is the greater. Humh! without Subscription! it must be Tricksy.) Father Aldo, prithee rid me of this Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Come, Son Limberham, we let our Friend Brainsick walk too long alone: shall we follow him? We must make haste; for I expect a whole Beavy of Whores, a Chamber-full of Temptation this Afternoon: 'tis my day of Audience.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Mr. Woodall, we leave you here, you remember?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let me alone. Ladies, your Servant; I have a little private business with a Friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Meaning me.—Well, Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Your Servant, till we meet again.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: My Note has taken, as I wish'd: he will be here immediately. If I cou'd but resolve to lose no time, out of modesty; but 'tis his part to be violent, for both our Credits. Never so little force and ruffling, and a poor weak Woman is excus'd. (Noise.) Hark, I hear him coming.—Ah me! the steps beat double: he comes not alone: If it shou'd be my Husband with him! where shall I hide my self? I see no other place, but under his Bed: I must lie as silently, as my fear will suffer me. Heav'n send me safe again to my own Chamber.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well, Fortune at the last is favourable, and now you are my Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: After a quarter of an hour, I suppose, I shall have my liberty upon easie terms. But pray let us parley a little first.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let it be upon the Bed then. Please you to sit?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No matter where: I am never the nearer to your wicked purpose. But you men are commonly great Comedians in Love-matters; therefore you must swear, in the first place—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, no Conditions: the Fortress is reduc'd to Extremity; and you must yield upon discretion, or I Storm.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Never to love any other Woman.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I kiss the Book upon't.
sp.stage: Kisses her. Mrs. Brain. pinches him from underneath the Bed.
sp.p: Oh, are you at your Love-tricks already? If you pinch me thus, I shall bite your Lip.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I did not pinch you: but you are apt, I see, to take any occasion of gathering up more close to me. Next, you shall not so much as look on Mrs. Brainsick.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Have you done? these Covenants are so tedious!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nay, but swear then.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I do promise, I do swear, I do any thing. (Mrs. Brain. runs a Pin into him) Oh, the Devil! what do you mean to run Pins into me? this is perfect Catter-wauling.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You fancy all this; I wou'd not hurt you for the World. Come, you shall see how well I love you.— (Kisses him: Mrs. Brain. pricks her.) Oh! I think you have Needles growing in your Bed.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'll see what's the matter in't.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: (Within.) Mr. Woodall, where are you, verily?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pox verily her; 'tis my Landlady: here, hide your self behind the Curtains, while I run to the door to stop her entry.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Necessity has no Law; I must be patient.

div.stage: She gets into the Bed, and draws the Cloaths over her.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: In sadness, Gentleman, I can hold no longer: I will not keep your wicked counsel, how you were lock'd up in the Chest; for it lies heavy upon my Conscience, and out it must, and shall.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You may tell, but who'll believe you? where's your witness?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, Heav'n is my witness.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That's your witness too, that you wou'd have allur'd me to lewdness, have seduc'd a hopeful young man, as I am; you wou'd have intic'd youth: mark that, Beldam.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: I care not; my single Evidence is enough to Mr. Limberham; he will believe me, that thou burn'st in unlawful Lust to his beloved: So thou shalt be an out-cast from my Family.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then will I go to the Elders of thy Church, and lay thee open before them, that thou did'st Feloniously unlock that Chest, with wicked intentions of purloyning: so thou shalt be Excommunicated from the Congregation, thou Jezebel, and deliver'd over to Satan.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p:
Verily, our Teacher will not Excommunicate me, for taking the Spoils of the Ungodly, to Cloath him; for it is a judg'd Case amongst us, that a marri'd VVoman may steal from her Husband, to
relieve a Brother. But yet thou may'st attone this difference betwixt us; verily, thou mayest.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Now thou art tempting me again. Well, if I had not the gift of Continency, what might become of me?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: The means have been offered thee, and thou hast kicked with the Heel: I will go immediately to the Tabernacle of Mr. Limberham, and discover thee, O thou Serpent, in thy crooked Paths.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hold, good Landlady, not so fast; let me have time to consider on't; I may mollifie, for Flesh is frail. An hour or two hence we will confer together upon the Premises.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Oh, on the sudden, I feel my self exceeding sick! Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Get you quickly to your Closet, and fall to your Mirabilis; this is no place for sick people. Be gone, be gone.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, I can go no farther.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But you shall, verily: I will thrust you down, out of pure pity.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Oh, my eyes grow dim! my heart quops, and my back aketh! here I will lay me down, and rest me.

div.stage: Throws her self suddenly down upon the Bed; Tricksy shrieks, and rises: Mrs. Brainsick rises from under the Bed in a Fright.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So! here's a fine business! my whole Seraglio up in Arms!

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: So, so; if Providence had not sent me hither, what folly had been this day committed!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh the Old Woman in the Oven! we both over-heard your Pious Documents: did we not, Mrs. Brainsick?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Yes, we did over-hear her, and we will both testifie against her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I have nothing to say for her. Nay, I told her her own; you can both bear me witness. If a sober man cannot be quiet in his own Chamber for her—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: For, you know, Sir, when Mrs. Brainsick and I over-heard her coming, having been before acquainted with her wicked purpose, we both agreed to trap her in it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: And now she wou'd scape her self, by accusing us! but let us both conclude to cast an Infamy upon her House, and leave it.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. VVoodall, intercede for me, or I shall be ruin'd.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Well, for once, I'll be good-natur'd, and try my interest. Pray, Ladies, for my sake, let this business go no farther.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Mrs. Brain. You may command us.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: For, look you, the offence was properly to my Person; and Charity has taught me to forgive my Enemies. I hope, Mistress Saintly, this will be a warning to you, to amend your life: I speak like a Christian, as one that tenders the welfare of your Soul.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, I will consider.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Why, that's well said.— (Aside.) Gad, and so must I too; for my People is dissatisfi'd, and my Government in danger: but this is no place for Meditation. Ladies, I wait on you.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: DIspatch, Geoffery, dispatch: the out lying Punks will be upon us, e're I am in a readiness to give Audience. Is the Office well provided?

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: The Stores are very low, Sir: some Doily Petticoats, and Manto's we have; and half a dozen pair of lac'd Shooes, bought from Court at second hand.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, there's not enough to rig out a Mournival of VVhores: they'l think me grown a meer Curmudgeon. Mercy on me, how will this glorious Trade be carri'd on, with such a miserable Stock!

sp.speaker: Geoff.
sp.p: I hear a Coach already stopping at the door.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: VVell, somewhat in ornament for the Body, somewhat in counsel for the mind; one thing must help out another, in this bad VVorld: VVhoring must go on.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Overdon, and her Daughter Pru.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Over.
sp.p: Ask blessing, Pru: he's the best Father you ever had.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Bless thee, and make thee a substantial, thriving VVhore. Have your Mother in your eye, Pru; 'tis good to follow good example: How old are you, Pru? hold up your head, Child.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Going o'my sixteen, Father Aldo.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: And you have been initiated but these two years: Ioss of time, loss of precious time. Mrs. Overdon, how much have you made of Pru, since she has been Man's meat?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Over.
sp.p: A very small matter, by my troth; considering the charges I have been at in her Education: poor Pru was born under an unluckie Planet; I despair of a Coach for her. Her first Maidenhead brought me in but little: the weather-beaten old Knight that bought her of me, beat down the price so low; I held her at an hundred Guinnies, and he bid ten; and higher than thirty he wou'd not rise.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: A pox of his unluckie handsel: he can but fumble, and will not pay neither.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Hang him; I cou'd never endure him, Father: he's the silthi'st old Goat; and then he comes every day to our house, and eats out his thirty Guinnies; and at three Months end, he threw me off.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Over.
sp.p: And since then, the poor Child has dwindled, and dwindled away: her next Maiden-head brought me but ten; and from ten she fell to five; and at last to a single Guinny: she has no luck to keeping; they all leave her, the more my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: VVe must get her a Husband then in the City; they bite rarely at a stale VVhore o'this end o'th' Town, new furbish'd up in a taudry Manto.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Over.
sp.p: No: pray let her try her fortune a little longer in the VVorld first: by my troth, I shou'd be loth to be at all this cost, in her French, and her Singing, to have her thrown away upon a Husband.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, there can come no good of your swearing, Mrs. Overdon: Say your Prayers, Pru, and go duly to Church o'Sundays, you'l thrive the better all the week. Come, have a good heart, Child; I'll keep thee my self: thou shalt do my little business; and I'll find thee an able young Fellow to do thine.
Daughter, Pad; you are welcome: what, you have perform'd the last Christian Office to your Keeper; I saw you follow him up the heavy Hill to Tyburn. Have you had never a business since his death?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pad.
sp.p: No indeed, Father; never since Execution-day: the night before, we lay together most lovingly in Newgate: and the next morning he lift up his eyes, and prepar'd his Soul with a Prayer, while one might tell twenty; and then mounted the Cart as merrily, as if he had been a going for a Purse.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: You are a sorrowful Widow, Daughter Pad; but I'll take care of you: Geoffery, see her rigg'd out immediately for a new Voyage: Look in Figure 9. in the upper Drawer, and give her out the Flower'd Justacorps, with the Petticoat belonging to't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pad.
sp.p: Cou'd you not help to prefer me, Father?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Let me see! let me see! Before George, I have it, and it comes as pat too! Go me to the very Judge who sate upon him; 'tis an amorous, impotent, old Magistrate, and keeps admirably: I saw him leer upon you from the Bench: he'll tell you what's sweeter than Straw berries and Cream, before you part.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Term.
sp.p: O Father, I think I shall go mad.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: You are of the violentest temper, Daughter Termagant! when had you a business last?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Term.
sp.p: The last I had was with young Caster, that Son of a Whore Gamester: he brought me to Taverns, to draw in young Cullies, while he bubbled 'em at Play: and when he had pick'd up a considerable Sum, and shou'd divide, the Cheating Dog wou'd sink my share, and swear, Dam him, he won nothing.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Unconscionable Villain, to cozen you in your own Calling!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Term.
sp.p: When he loses upon the Square, he comes home Zoundzing and Blooding; first beats me unmercifully, and then squeezes me to the last Penny: he has us'd me so, that Gad forgive me, I cou'd almost forswear my Trade: the Rogue starves me too: he made me keep Lent last year till Whitsontide, and out-fac'd me with Oaths, it was but Easter. And what mads me most, I carry a Bastard of the Rogues in my Belly: and now he turns me off, and will not own it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Over.
sp.p: Lord, how it quops! you are half a year gone, Madam—

div.stage: Laying her hand on her Belly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Term.
sp.p: I feel the young Rascal kicking already, like his Father— Oh, there's an Elbow thrusting out: I think in my Conscience he's Palming and Topping in my Belly; and practising for a livelihood before he comes into the World.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Geoffrey, set her down in the Register, that I may provide her a Mid-wife, and a Dry and Wet Nurse: when you are up again, as Heav'n send you a good hour, we'll pay him off at Law i'faith. You have him under black and white, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Term.
sp.p: Yes, I have a Note under his hand for 200 l.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: A Note under's hand! that's a Chip in Porridge; 'tis just nothing. Look, Geoffrey, to the Figure 12. for old Half-shirts for Child-bed Linnen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hack.
sp.p: O, Madam Termagant, are you here! Justice, Father Aldo, Justice.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, Daughter Hackney?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: She has violated the Law of Nations; for yesterday she inveigled my own natural Cully from me, a marri'd Lord, and made him false to my Bed, Father.

sp.speaker: Term.
sp.p: Come, you are an illiterare Whore: He's my Lord now; and, though you call him Fool, 'tis well know he's a Critick, Gentlewoman. You never read a Play in all your life; and I gain'd him by my Wit, and so I'll keep him.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: My comfort is, I have had the best of him; he can take up no more, till his Father dies: and so, much good may do you with my Cully, and my Clap into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Then there's a Father for your Child, my Lord's Son and Heir by Mr. Caster: but henceforward, to preserve peace betwixt you, I ordain, that you shall ply no more in my Daughter Hackney's Quarter's: you shall have the City, from White-Chappel to Temple-Bar, and she shall have to Covent-Garden downwards: At the Play-houses, she shall ply the Boxes, because she has the better face; and you shall have the Pit, because you can prattle best out of a Vizor-Mask.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pad.
sp.p: Then all Friends, and Confederates: Now let's have Father Aldo's delight, and so Adjourn the House.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Well said, Daughter: lift up your Voices, and sing like Nightingales, you Tory Rory Jades. Courage, I say; as long as the merry Pence hold out, you shall none of you die in Shoreditch.
A hey, Boys, a hey! here he comes that will swinge you all! down, you little Jades, and worship him; 'tis the Genius of Whoring.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And down went Chairs and Table, and out went every Candle. Ho, brave old Patriarch in the middle of the Church Militant! Whores of all sorts; Forkers and Ruine-tail'd: now come I gingling in with my Bells, and fly at the whole Covey.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: A hey, a hey, Boys, the Town's thy own; burn, ravish, and destroy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: We'll have a Night on't; like Alexander, when he burnt Persepolis: tue, tue, tue; point de quartier.

div.stage: He runs in amongst'em, and they scuttle about the Room.
Enter Saintly, Pleasance, Judith, with Broom-sticks.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: What, in the midst of Sodom! O thou lewd young Man! My Indignation boils over against these Harlots; and thus I sweep 'em from out my Family.

sp.speaker: Plea.
sp.p: Down with the Suburbians, down with 'em.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: O, spare my Daughters, Mrs. Saintly: sweet Mrs. Pleasance, spare my Flesh and Blood.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Keep the door open, and help to secure the Retreat, Father: there's no pity to be expected.

div.stage: The Whores run out, follow'd by Saintly, Pleasance, and Judith.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Welladay, welladay! one of my Daughters is big with Bastard, and she laid at her Gascoins most unmercifully! every stripe she had, I felt it: the first fruit of Whoredom is irrecoverably lost!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Make haste, and comfort her.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I will, I will: and yet I have a vexatious business which calls me first another way: the Rogue, my Son, is certainly come over; he has been seen in Town four days ago!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible: I'll not believe it.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: A Friend of mine met his Old Man Giles, this very morning, in quest of me; and Giles assur'd him, his Master is lodg'd in this very Street.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: In this very Street! how knows he that?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: He dogg'd him to the corner of it: and then my Son turn'd back, and threaten'd him. But I'll find out Giles, and then I'll make such an Example of my Reprobate!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If Giles be discover'd, I am undone! Why, Gervase, where are you, Sirrah! Hey, hey!

Run quickly to that betraying Rascal Giles, a Rogue, who wou'd take Judas his Bargain out of his hands, and under-sell him: Command him strictly to mew himself up in his Lodgings, till farther Orders: and in case he be refractory, let him know, I have not forgot to kick and cudgel. That Memento wou'd do well for you too, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Thank your Worship, you have always been liberal of your hands to me.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: And you have richly deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I will not say who has better deserv'd it, of my old Master.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Away, old Epictetus, about your business, and leave your musty Morals, or I shall—

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Nay, I won't forfeit my own wisdom so far, as to suffer for it. Rest you merry: I'll do my best, and Heav'n mend all.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, I have waited till you were alone, and am come to rebuke you, out of the zeal of my Spirit.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: 'Tis the Spirit of Persecution: Dioclesian, and Julian the Apostate, were but Types of thee. Get thee hence, thou old Geneva Testament: thou art a part of the Ceremonial Law, and hast been abolish'd these twenty years.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: All this is nothing, Sir; I am privy to your Plots: I'll discover 'em to Mr. Limberham, and make the House too hot for you.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: What, you can talk in the Language of the World, I see!

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: I can, I can, Sir; and in the Language of the Flesh and Devil too, if you provoke me to Despair: you must, and shall be mine, this night.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: The very Ghost of Queen Dido in the Ballad.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Delay no longer, or—

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Or! you will not swear, I hope?

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Ʋds Niggers, but I will; and that so loud, that Mr. Limberham shall hear me.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p:
Ʋds Niggers, I confess, is a very dreadful Oath: you cou'd
lye naturally before, as you are a Fanatick: if you can swear such Rappers too, there's hope of you; you may be a Woman of the World in time. Well, you shall be satisfi'd, to the utmost farthing: to night, and in your own Chamber.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Or, expect to morrow—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: All shall be atton'd e're then. Go, provide the Bottle of Clary, the Westphalia Ham, and other Fortifications of Nature; we shall see what may be done: what, an old Woman must not be cast away.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Then, verily, I am appeas'd.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, no relapsing into Verily; that's in our Bargain. Look how she weeps for joy! 'Tis a good old Soul, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: You wi' not fail?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Dost thou think I have no compassion for thy grey hairs? Away, away; our love may be discover'd: we must avoid Scandal; 'tis thy own Maxim.
They are all now at Ombre; and Brainsick's Maid has promis'd to send her Mistress up.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: (Aside) I'll conquer my proud Spirit, I'm resolv'd on't, and speak kindly to him.—What, alone, Sir! If my company be not troublesome; or a tender young Creature, as I am, may safely trust her self with a man of such Prowess, in Love affairs—It wonnot be.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So! there's one Broad-side already: I must shear off.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: What, you have been pricking up and down here upon a cold scent; but, at last, you have hit it off, it seems! Now for a fair view at the Wife or Mistress! up the wind, and away with it: Heigh, Jouler! — I think I am bewitch'd, I cannot hold.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Your servant, your servant, Madam: I am in a little haste at present.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Pray resolve me first, for which of 'em you lie in Ambush: for, methinks, you have the Meen of a Spider in her Den: Come, I know the Web is spread, and, who ever comes, Sir Cranion stands ready to dart out, hale her in, and shed his Venom.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) But such a terrible Wasp, as she, will spoil the Snare, if I durst tell her so.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: 'Tis unconscionably done of me, to debar you the Freedom and Civilities of the House. Alas, poor Gentleman! to take a Lodging at so dear a rate, and not to have the benefit of his Bargain!— Mischief on me, what needed I have said that?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The Dialogue will go no farther: Farewel, gentle, quiet Lady.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Pray stay a little; I'll not leave you thus.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I know it; and therefore mean to leave you first.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: O, I find it now; you are going to set up your Bills, like a Love-Mountebank, for the speedy cure of distressed Widows, old Ladies, and languishing Maids in the Green sickness: a Soveraign Remedy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That last, for Maids, wou'd be thrown away: few of your Age are qualifi'd for the Medicine. What the Devil wou'd you be at, Madam?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I am in the humour of giving you good counsel. The Wife can afford you but the leavings of a Fop; and to a witty man, as you think your self, that's nauseous: The Mistress has fed upon Fool so long, she's Carrion too, and Common into the Bargain. Wou'd you beat a Ground for Game in the Afternoon, when my Lord Mayor's Pack had been before you in the morning?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I had rather sit five hours at one of his greasie Feasts, than hear you talk.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Your two Mistresses keep both Shop and Ware-house; and what they cannot put off, in Gross, to the Keeper and the Husband, they sell by Retail to the next Chance-customer. Come, are you edifi'd?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'm considering how to thank you for your Homily: and to make a sober Application of it, you may have some laudable design your self in this advice.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Meaning, some secret inclination to that amiable Person of yours?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I confess, I am vain enough to hope it: for why shou'd you remove the two Dishes, but to make me fall more hungrily on the third?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Perhaps, indeed, in the way of Honour—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Paw, paw! that word Honour has almost turn'd my Stomach: it carries a villanous interpretation of Matrimony along with it. But, in a civil way, I cou'd be content to deal with you, as the Church does with the Heads of your Fanaticks, offer you a lusty Benefice to stop your mouth; if fifty Guinnies, and a courtesie more worth, will win you.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Out upon thee! fifty Guinnies! Dost thou think I'll sell my self? and at Play-house price too? When ever I go, I go altogether: no cutting from the whole Piece; he who has me, shall have the fag end with the rest, I warrant him. Be satisfi'd, thy Sheers shall never enter into my Cloth. But, look to thy self, thou impudent Belswagger: I'll be reveng'd; I will.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p:
The Maid will give warning, that's my comfort; for she is brib'd on my side. I have another kind of Love to this Girl, than to either of the other two; but a Fanatick's Daughter, and the
Noose of Matrimony, are such intolerable terms! O, here she comes, who will sell me better cheap?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: How now, Sir? what impudence is this of yours, to approach my Lodgings?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: You lately honour'd mine: and 'tis the part of a well-bred man, to return your Visit

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: If I cou'd have imagin'd how base a Fellow you had been, you shou'd not then have been troubled with my company.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How cou'd I guess, that you intended me the Favour, without first acquainting me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: Cou'd I do it, ungrateful as you are, with more obligation to you, or more hazard to my self, than by putting my Note into your Glove?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Was it yours then? I believ'd it came from Mrs. Tricksy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: You wish'd it so; which made you so easily believe it. I heard the pleasant Dialogue betwixt you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I am glad you did: for you cou'd not but observe, with how much care I avoided all occasions of railing at you; to which she urg'd me, like a malicious Woman, as she was.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: By the same token, you vow'd and swore never to look on Mrs. Brainsick!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But I had my Mental Reservations in a readiness. I had vow'd fidelity to you before; and there went my second Oath, i'faith: it vanish'd in a twinkling, and never gnaw'd my Conscience in the least.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: Well, I shall never heartily forgive you.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: (Within) Mr. Brainsick, Mr. Brainsick, what do you mean, to make my Lady lose her Game thus? Pray come back, and take up her Cards again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: My Husband, as I live! Well, for all my quarrel to you, step immediately into that little dark Closet: 'tis for my private occasions; there's no Lock, but he wi'not stay.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Thus am I ever Tantaliz'd?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: What, am I become your Drudge? your Slave? the Property of all your pleasures? Shall I, the Lord and Master of your Life, become subservient; and the Noble Name of Husband be dishonour'd? No, though all the Cards were Kings and Queens, and Indies to be gain'd by every Deal—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: My dear, I am coming to do my duty. I did but go up a little, (I whisper'd you for what) and am returning immediately.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Your Sex is but one Universal Ordure, a Nusance, and incumbrance of that Majestick Creature, Man: yet I my self am mortal too, Nature's necessities have call'd me up; produce your Utensil of Urine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: 'Tis not in the way, Child: you may go down into the Garden.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: The Voyage is too far: though the way were pay'd with Pearls and Diamonds, every step of mine is precious, as the March of Monarchs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: Then my steps, which are not so precious, shall be imploid for you: I'll call up Judith.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: I will not dance attendance. At the present, your Closet shall be honour'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: O Lord, Dear, 'tis not worthy to receive such a man as you are.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Nature presses; I am in haste.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: He must be discover'd, and I unavoidably undone!

div.stage: Aside. Brainsick goes to the Door, and Woodall meets him: She shricks out.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Mounsieur Woodall!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sir, be gone, and make no noise, or you'l spoil all.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Spoil all, quoth a! what does he mean, in the name of Wonder?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Taking him aside) Hark you, Mr. Brainsick, is the Devil in you, that you, and your Wife come hither, to disturb my Intrigue, which you your self ingag'd me in, with Mrs. Trickey, to revenge you on Limberham? Why, I had made an appointment with her here; but, hearing some-body come up, I retir'd into the Closet, till I was satisfi'd 'twas not the Keeper.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: But why this Intrigue in my Wife's Chamber?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, you turn my Brains, with talking to me of your Wife's Chamber! do you lie in common? the Wife and Husband, the Keeper and the Mistress?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: I am afraid they are quarrelling; pray Heav'n I get off.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Once again, I am the Sultan of this place: Mr. Limberham is the Mogol of the next Mansion.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Though I am a stranger in the House, 'tis impossible I shou'd be so much mistaken: I say, this is Limberham's Lodging.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: You wou'd not venture a wager of ten pounds that you are not mistaken?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis done: I'll lay you.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Who shall be Judge?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Who better than your Wife? She cannot be partial, because she knows not on which side you have laid.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Content. Come hither, Lady mine: whose Lodgings are these? who is Lord, and Grand Seignior of 'em?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: (Aside) Oh, goes it there? — Why shou'd you ask me such a question, when every body in the house can tell they are n'one Dears?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Now are you satisfi'd? Children, and Fools, you know the Proverb.—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pox on me; nothing but such a positive Coxcomb as I am, wou'd have laid his money upon such odds; as if you did not know your own Lodgings better than I, at half a days warning! And that which vexes me more than the loss of my Money, is the loss of my Adventure!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: It shall be spent: we'll have a Treat with it. This is a Fool of the first Magnitude.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: Let n'one Dear alone, to find a Fool out.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Bully Brainsick, Pug has sent me to you on an Embassie, to bring you down to Cards again; she's in her Mulligrubs already; she'll never forgive you the last Vol you won. 'Tis but losing a little to her, out of complaisance, as they say, to a fair Lady: and what e're she wins, I'll make up to you again in private.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: I wou'd not be that Slave you are, to enjoy the Treasures of the East: the possession of Peru, and of Potozi, shou'd not buy me to the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Will you leave your Perbole's, and come then?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: No, for I have won a Wager, to be spent luxuriously at Longs; with Pleasance of the Party, and Termagant Tricksy; and I will pass, in Person, to the preparation: Come, Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: To him; I'll second you: now for mischief!

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Arise, Mr. Limberham, arise; for Conspiracies are hatch'd against you, and a new Faux is preparing to blow up your happiness.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: What's the matter, Landlady? Prithee speak, good honest English, and leave thy Canting.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p:
Verily, thy Beloved is led astray, by the Young Man Woodall, that Vessel of Uncleanness: I beheld them communing together; she feigned her self sick, and retired to her Tent in the Garden-house;
and I watched her out-going, and behold he follow'd her.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Do you stand unmov'd, and hear all this?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Before George, I am Thunder-struck!

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Take to thee thy resolution, and avenge thy self.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: But give me leave to consider first: a man must do nothing rashly.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I cou'd tear out the Villains eyes, for dishonouring you, while you stand considering, as you call it. Are you a man, and suffer this?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Yes, I am a man; but a man's but a man, you know: I am recollecting my self, how these things can be.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: How they can be! I have heard 'em; I have seen 'em.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Heard 'em, and seen 'em! It may be so; but yet I cannot enter into this same business: I am amaz'd, I must confess; but the best is, I do not believe one word on't.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Make haste, and thine own eyes shall testifie against her.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, if my own eyes testifie, it may be so.—But 'tis impossible however; for I am making a Settlement upon her, this very day.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Look, and satisfie your self, e're you make that Settlement on so false a Creature.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: But yet, if I shou'd look; and not find her false, then I must cast in another hundred, to make her satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Was there ever such a meek, Hen-hearted Creature!

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, thou hast not the Spirit of a Cock-Chicken.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Before George, but I have the Spirit of a Lion, and I will tear her limb from limb—if I cou'd believe it.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Love, Jealousy, and disdain, how they torture me at once! and this insensible creature—were I but in his place.—(To him.) Think, that this very instant she's yours no more: now, now she's giving up her self, with so much violence of Love, that if Thunder roar'd, she cou'd not hear it.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: I have been whetting all this while: they shall be so taken in the manner, that Mars and Venus shall be nothing to 'em.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Make haste; go on then.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Yes, I will go on;—and yet my mind misgives me Plaguily.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Again backsliding!

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Have you no sense of Honour in you?

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Well, Honor is Honor, and I must go: but I shall never get me such another Pug again! O, my heart! my poor tender heart! 'tis just breaking, with Pug's unkindness!

div.head: SCENE II. Woodall and Tricksy discover'd in the Garden-house.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Make haste, and save your self, Sir; the Enemy's at hand: I have discover'd him from the corner, where you set me Sentry.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Who is't?

sp.speaker: Gerv.
sp.p: Who shou'd it be, but Limberham? Arm'd with a two-hand Fox. O Lord, O Lord!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Enter quickly into the Still-house both of you, and leave me to him: there's a Spring-lock within, to open it when we are gone.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well, I have won the party and revenge however: a minute longer, and I had won the Tout.

div.stage: They go in: She locks the door.
Enter Limberham, with a great Sword.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Disloyal Pug.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What humor's this? you're drunk it seems: go sleep.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Thou hast robb'd me of my repose for ever: I am like Mackbeth, after the death of good King Duncan; methinks a voice says to me, Sleep no more; Tricksy has murder'd Sleep.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Now I find it: you are willing to save your Settlement, and are sent by some of your wise Counsellors, to pick a quarrel with me.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: I have been your Cully above these seven years; but, at last my eyes are open'd to your Witchcraft: and indulgent Heav'n has taken a care of my preservation.—In short, Madam, I have found you out; and to cut off preambles, produce your Adulterer.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: If I have any, you know him best: you are the only ruin of my reputation. But if I have dishonor'd my Family, for the love of you, methinks you shou'd be the last man to upbraid me with it.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: I am sure you are of the Family of your abominable great Grandam Eve; But produce the man, or, by my Fathers Soul—

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Still I am in the dark.

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: Yes, you have been in the dark; I know it: but I shall bring you to light immediately.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You are not jealous.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: No; I am too certain to be jealous: but you have a man here, that shall be nameless; let me see him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
O, if that be your business, you had best search: and when
you have weari'd your self, and spent your idle humor, you may find me above, in my Chamber, and come to ask my pardon.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: You may go, Madam; but I shall beseech your Ladiship to leave the Key of the Still-house door behind you: I have a mind to some of the Sweet-meats you have lock'd up there; you understand me. Now, for the old Dog-trick! you have lost the Key, I know already, but I am prepar'd for that; you shall know you have no Fool to deal with.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No; here's the Key: take it, and satisfie your foolish curiosity.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: (Aside) This confidence amazes me! If those two Gipsies have abus'd me, and I shou'd not find him there now, this wou'd make an immortal quarrel.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Aside) I have put him to a stand.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Hang't, 'tis no matter; I will be satisfi'd: if it comes to a rupture, I know the way to buy my peace. Pug, produce the Key.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Takes him about the Neck) My Dear, I have it for you: Come, and kiss me. Why wou'd you be so unkind to suspect my Faith now? when I have forsaken all the World for you.— (Kiss again) But I am not in the mood of quarrelling to night; I take this Jealousie the best way, as the effect of your passion. Come up, and we'll go to Bed together, and be Friends.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: (Aside) Pug's in a pure humor to night, and 'twou'd vex a man to lose it; but yet I must be satisfi'd? And therefore, upon mature consideration, give me the Key.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You are resolv'd then?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Yes, I am resolv'd; for I have sworn to my self by Styx: and that's an irrevocable Oath.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Now, see your folly: there's the Key.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Why, that's a loving Pug; I will prove thee Innocent immediately: and that will put an end to all Controversies betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Yes, it shall put an end to all our quarrels: farewel for the last time, Sir. Look well upon my face, that you may remember it; for, from this time forward, I have sworn it irrevocably too, that you shall never see it more.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, but hold a little, Pug. What's the meaning of this new Commotion?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No more; but satisfie your foolish fancy, for you are Master: And besides, I am willing to be justifi'd.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Then you shall be justifi'd.

div.stage: Puts the Key in the door.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I know I shall: farewel.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: But, are you sure you shall?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, no, he's there: you'l find him up in the Chimney, or behind the door; or, it may be, crouded into some little Galley-Pot.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: But you will not leave me, if I shou'd look?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You are not worth my answer: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Divine Pug, and let me recollect a little.— This is no time for meditation neither: while I deliberate, she may be gone. She must be Innocent, or she cou'd never be so confident, and careless.—Sweet Pug, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I am provok'd too far.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: 'Tis the property of a Goddess to forgive. Accept of this Oblation; with this humble kiss, I here present it to thy fair hand: I conclude thee Innocent without looking, and depend wholly upon thy mercy.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, keep it, keep it: the Lodgings are your own.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: If I shou'd keep it, I were unworthy of forgiveness: I will no longer hold this fatal Instrument of our Separation.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Taking it) Rise, Sir: I will endeavour to overcome my Nature, and forgive you; for I am so scrupulously nic • in Love, that it grates my very Soul to be suspected: Yet, take my counsel, and satisfie your self.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I wou'd not be satisfi'd, to be Possessor of Pot • zi, as my Brother Brainsick says. Come, to Bed, dear Pug. Now wou'd not I change my condition, to be an Eastern Monarch.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, are we alive!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Alive! why, we were never in any danger: well, she's a rare Menager of a Fool!

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Are you dispos'd yet to receive good counsel? has affliction wrought upon you?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, I must ask thy advice in a most important business: I have promis'd a Charity to Mrs. Saintly, and she expects it with a beating heart a-bed: Now, I have at present no running Cash to throw away, my ready Money is all paid to Mrs. Tricksy, and the Bill is drawn upon me for to night.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Take advice of your Pillow.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, since you have not the grace to offer yours, I will for once make use of my Authority, and command you to perform the foresaid Drudgery in my place.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Zookers, I cannot answer it to my Conscience.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, and your Conscience can suffer you to swear, it shall suffer you to lie too: I mean in this sense. Come, no denial, you must do it; she's rich, and there's a provision for your life.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir, have pity on my Soul.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Have you pity of your Body: there's all the Wages you must expect.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you have perswaded me: I will arm my Conscience with a resolution of making her an honourable amends by Marriage; for to morrow morning a Parson shall authorize my labours, and turn Fornication into duty. And moreover, I will enjoyn my self, by way of Penance, not to touch her for seven nights after.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Thou wert predestinated for a Husband I see, by that natural Instinct: as we walk, I will instruct thee how to behave thy self, with secresie and silence.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I have a Key of the Garden, to let us out the back way into the Street, and so privately to our Lodging.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis well: I'll plot the rest of my affairs a-bed; for 'tis resolv'd that Limberham shall not wear Horns alone: and I am impatient till I add to my Trophy the Spoils of Brainsick.

div.head: ACT. V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: WEll, you are a lucky man! Mrs. Brainsick is Fool enough to believe you wholly Innocent; and that the Adventure of the Garden-house last night, was only a Vision of Mrs. Saintly's.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I knew, if I cou'd once speak with her, all wou'd be set right immediately; for, had I been there, look you,—

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: As you were, most certainly.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Limberham must have found me out; that Fe-fa-fum of a Keeper wou'd have smelt the blood of a Cuckold-maker: they say, he was peeping and butting about in every cranny.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: But one. You must excuse my unbelief, though Mrs. Brainfick is better satisfi'd. She and her Husband, you know, went out this morning to the New Exchange: there she has given him the slip; and pretending to call at her Taylors, to try her. Stays for a new Gown.—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I understand thee. She fetch'd me a short turn, like a Hare before her Muse, and will immediately run hither to Covert?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Yes; but because your Chamber will be least suspitious, she appoints to meet you there; that, if her Husband shou'd come back, he may think her still abroad, and you may have time —

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
To take in the Horn work. It happens as I wish; for Mistress Tricksy, and her Keeper, are gone out with Father Aldo, to compleat her Settlement: my Landlady is safe at her Morning Exercise,
with my Man Gervase, and her Daughter not stirring: the House is our own, and Iniquity may walk bare-fac'd.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: And, to make all sure, I am order'd to be from home. When I come back again, I shall knock at your door, with speak Brother, speak; is the deed done?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Long ago, long ago; and then we come panting out together. Oh, I am ravish'd with the imagination on't!

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Well, I must retire; Good-morrow to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Now do I humbly conceive, that this Mistress in Matrimony, will give me more pleasure than the former: for your coupled Spaniels, when they are once let loose, are afterwards the highest Rangers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: Oh dear Mr. Woodall, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Recover breath, and I'll instruct you in the next Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: But my Husbaud follows me at heels.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Has he seen you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: I hope not: I thought I had left him sure enough, at the Exchange; but, looking behind me, as I entred into the house, I saw him walking a round rate this way.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Since he has not seen you, there's no danger: you need but step into my Chamber, and there we'll lock our selves up, and transform him in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: I had rather have got into my own; but Judith is gone out with the Key, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, by your appointment. But so much the better; for when the Cuckold finds no company, he will certainly go a santring again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: Make haste then.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Immediately.—(Goes to open the door hastily, and breaks his Key.) What's the matter here? the Key turns round, and will not open! As I live, we are undone! with too much haste 'tis broken!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: Then I am lost; for I cannot enter into my own.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This next Room is Limberham's. See! the door's open; and he and his Mistress are both abroad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: There's no remedy, I must venture in: for his knowing I am come back so soon, must be cause of jealousie enough, if the Fool shou'd find me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Looking in) See there! Mrs. Tricksy has left her Indian Gown upon the Bed; clap it on, and turn your back: he will easily mistake you for her, if he shou'd look in upon you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: I'll put on my Vizor-Mask however, for more security. (Noise) Hark! I hear him.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: What, in a musty musing, Monsieur Woodall! Let me enter into the Affair.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You may guess it, by the Post I have taken up.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: O, at the door of the Damsel Tricksy! your business is known by your abode; as the posture of a Porter before a Gate, denotes to what Family he belongs. (Looks in.) 'Tis an Assignation I see: for yonder she stands, with her back toward me, drest up for the Duel, with all the Ornaments of the East. Now for the Judges of the Field, to divide the Sun and Wind betwixt the Combatants, and a tearing Trumpeter to sound the Charge.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis a private quarrel, to be decided without Seconds; and therefore you wou'd do me a favour to withdraw.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Your Limberham is nearer than you imagine: I left him almost entring at the door.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Plague of all impertinent Cuckolds! they are ever troublesome to us honest Lovers: so intruding!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: They are indeed, where their company is not desir'd.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sure he has some Tutelar Devil to guard his Brows! just when she had bobb'd him, and made an Errand home, to come to me!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: 'Tis unconscionably done of him. But you shall not adjourn your love for this; the Brainsick has an Ascendant over him: I am your Garantee; he's doom'd a Cuckold, in disdain of Destiny.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: To stand before the door with my brandish'd Blade, and defend the Entrance: he dies, upon the point, if he approaches.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If I durst trust it, 'tis Heroick.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: 'Tis the Office of a Friend: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) Shou'd he know hereafter his Wife were here, he wou'd think I had enjoy'd her, though I had not: 'tis best venturing for something. He takes pains enough o'conscience for his Cuckoldom; and, by my troth, has earn'd it fairly.—But, may a man venture upon your promise?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Bars of Brass, and doors of Adamant, cou'd not more secure you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I know it; but still gentle means are best: you may come to force at last. Perhaps, you may wheedle him away: 'tis but drawing a Trope or two upon him.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: He shall have it; with all the Artillery of Eloquence.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I, I; your Figure breaks no bones. With your good leave.—

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Thou hast it, Boy. Turn to him, Madam; to her Woodall: and S. George for merry England. Tan ta ra ra ra, ra ra! Dub, a dub, dub; Tan ta ra ra ra.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: How now, Bully Brainsick! What, upon the Tan ta ra, by your self?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Clangor, Taratantara, Murmur.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Commend me to honest Lingua Franca. Why, this is enough to stun a Christian, with your Hebrew, and your Creek, and such like Latin.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Out, Ignorance!

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Then Ignorance, by your leave; for I must enter.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Why in such haste? the Fortune of Greece depends not on't.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: But Pug' Fortune does: that's dearer to me than Greece, and sweeter than Ambergrise.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: You'l not find her here. Come, you are jealous: you're haunted with a raging Fiend, that robs you of your sweet repose.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, and you are in your Perbol • 's again! Look you, 'tis Pug is jealous of her Jewels: she has left the Key of her Cabinet behind; and has desir'd me to bring it back to her.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Poor Fool! he little thinks she's here before him! Well, this pretence will never pass on me; for I dive deeper into your affairs: you are jealous. But, rather than my Soul shou'd be concern'd for a Sex so insignificant,— Ha! the Gods! If I thought my proper Wife were now within, and prostituting all her Treasures to the lawless love of an Adulterer, I wou'd stand as intrepid, as firm, and as unmov'd, as the Statue of a Roman Gladiator.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: (In the same tone) Of a Roman Gladiator! — Now are you as mad as a March Hare; but I am in haste, to return to Pug: yet, by your favour, I will first secure the Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: No, you must not.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Must not? what, may not a man come by you, to look upon his own Goods and Chattels, in his own Chamber?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: No: with this Sabre, I defie the Destinies, and dam up the passage with my person; like a rugged Rock, oppos'd against the roaring of the boisterous Billows. Your jealousie shall have no course through me, though Potentates and Princes—

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Prithee what have we to do with Potentates and Princes? Will you leave your Troping, and let me pass?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: You have your utmost answer.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: If this Maggot bite a little deeper, we shall have you a Citizen of Bet'lem yet e're Dog-days. Well, I say little; but I'll tell Pug on't.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p:
She knows it already, by your favour.— Knocking. Sound a Retreat, you lusty Lovers, or the Enemy will Charge you in
the Flank, with a fresh Reserve: March off, march off upon the Spur, e're he can reach you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How now, Baron Tell-clock, is the passage clear?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Clear as a Level, without Hills or Woods, and void of Ambuscade.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But Limberham will return immediately, when he finds not his Mistress where he thought he left her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Friendship, which has done much, will yet do more. (Shows a Key.) With this Pusse par tout, I will instantly conduct her to my own Chamber, that she may out-face the Keeper she has been there; and, when my Wife returns, who is my Slave, I will lay my Conjugal Commands upon her, to affirm, they have been all this time together.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I shall never make you amends for this kindness, my dear Padron: but won'd it not be better, if you wou'd take the pains to run after Limberham, and stop him in his way e're he reach the place where he thinks he left his Mistress; then hold him in discourse as long as possibly you can, till you guess your Wife may be return'd, that so they may appear together?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: I warrant you: laissez faire a Marc Antoine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Now, Madam, you may venture out in safety.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: (Entring) Pray Heav'n I may.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hark! I hear Judith's voice: it happens well that she's return'd: slip into your Chamber immediately, and send back the Gown.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra.
sp.p: I will: but are not you a wicked man, to put me into all this danger?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Let what can happen, my comfort is, at least, I have enjoy'd: But this is no place for consideration. Be jogging, good Mr. Woodall, out of this Family, while you are well; and go Plant in some other Country, where your Virtues are not so famous.

div.stage: Enter Tricksy, with a Box of Writings.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What, wandring up and down, as if you wanted an owner? Do you know that I am Lady of the Mannour; and that all Wefts and Strays belong to me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I have walted for you above an hour; but Fryer Bacon's Head has been lately speaking to me, that Time is past. In a word, your Keeper has been here, and will return immediately; we must defer our happiness till some more favourable time.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
I fear him not; he has, this morning, arm'd me against himself,
by this Settlement: the next time he rebels, he gives me a fair occasion of leaving him for ever.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But is this Conscience in you? not to let him have his Bargain, when he has paid so dear for't.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You do not know him: he must perpetually be us'd ill, or he insults. Besides, I have gain'd an absolute Dominion over him: he must not see, when I bid him wink. If you argue after this, either you love me not, or dare not.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Go in, Madam: I was never dar'd before. I'll but Scout a little, and follow you immediately.— (Trick. goes in.) I find a Mistress is only kept for other men: and the Keeper is but her Man, in a green Livery, bound to serve a Warrant for the Doe, when e're she pleases, or is in season.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Still you're a lucky man! Mr. Brainsick has been exceeding honourable: he ran, as if a Legion of Bayliffs had been at his heels, and overtook Limberham in the Street. Here, take the Gown; lay it where you found it, and the danger's over.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Speak softly: Mrs. Tricksy is return'd. (Looks in.) Oh, she's gone into her Closet, to lay up her Writings: I can throw it on the Bed, e're she perceive it has been wanting.—

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Every Woman wou'd not have done this for you, which I have done.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I am sensible of it, little Judith: there's a time to come-shall pay for all. I hear her a returning: not a word; away.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What, is a second Summons needful? my, Favours have not been so cheap, that they shou'd stick upon my hands. It seems, you slight your Bill of fare, because you know it: or fear to be invited to your loss.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I was willing to secure my happiness from interruption: A true Souldier never falls upon the Plunder, while the Enemy is in the Field.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He has been so often baffled, that he grows contemptible. Were he here, shou'd he see you enter into my Closet; yet—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You are like to be put upon the tryal; for I hear his voice.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: 'Tis so: go in, and mark the event now: be but as unconcern'd, as you are safe, and trust him to my management.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I must venture it: because to be seen here, wou'd have the same effect, as to be taken within. Yet I doubt you are too confident.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: How now, Pug? return'd so soon!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: When I saw you came not for me, I was Ioth to be long without you.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: But which way came you, that I saw you not?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The back way; by the Garden door.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: How long have you been here?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Just come before you.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: O, then all's well. For, to tell you true, Pug, I had a kind of villanous apprehension that you had been here longer: but what e're thou say'st, is an Oracle, sweet Pug, and I am satisfi'd.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: (Aside) How infinitely she gulls him! and he so stupid not to find it! (To her) If he be still within, Madam, (you know my meaning?) here's Bilbo ready to forbid your Keeper entrance.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: (Aside) Woodall must have told him of our appointment.— What think you of walking down, Mr. Limberham?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I'il but visit the Chamber a little first.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What new Maggot's this? you dare not sure be jealous!

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: No, I protest, sweet Pug, I am not: only to satisfie my curiosity; that's but reasonable, you know.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Come, what foolish curiosity?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: You must know, Pug, I was going but just now, in obedience to your Commands, to enquire of the health and safety of your Jewels, and my Brother Brainsick most barbarously forbade me entrance: (nay, I dare accuse you, when Pug's by to back me;) but now I am resolv'd I will go see 'em, or some-body shall smoak for't.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: But I resolve you shall not. If she pleases to command my Person, I can comply with the obligation of a Cavalier.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But what reason had you to forbid him then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I, what reason had you to forbid me then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: 'Twas only my Caprichio, Madam. (Now must I seem ignorant, of what she knows full well.)

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: We'll enquire the cause at better leisure: Come down, Mr. Limberham.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, if it were only his Caprichio, I am satisfi'd: though, I must tell you, I was in a kind of huff, to hear him Tan ta ra, tan ta ra, a quarter of an hour together; for Tan ta ra is but an odd kind of sound, you know, before a man's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: (Aside) Judith has assur'd me he must be there; and, I'm resolv'd, I'll satisfie my revenge at any rate upon my Rivals.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Mrs. Pleasance is come to call us: pray let us go.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Oh dear, Mr. Limberham, I have had the dreadful'st Dream to night, and am come to tell it you; I dream'd you left your Mistress Jewels in your Chamber, and the Door open.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: In good time be it spoken; and so I did, Mrs. Pleasance.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And that a great swinging Thief came in, and whipt 'em out.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Marry, Heav'n forbid.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: This is ridiculous: I'll speak to your Mother, Madam, not to suffer you to eat such heavy Suppers.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, that's very true; for, you may remember, she fed very much upon Larks and Pigeons; and they are very heavy meat, as Pug says.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The Jewels are all safe; I look'd on 'em.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Will you never stand corrected, Mrs. Pleasance?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Not by you: correct your Matrimony. And methought, of a sudden, this Thief was turn'd to Mr. Woodall; and that, hearing Mr. Limberham come, he slipt for fear into the Closet.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I look'd all over it; I'm sure he is not there. Come away, Dear.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: What, I think you are in a Dream too, Brother Limberham.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: If her Dream shou'd come out now! 'tis good to be sure however.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You are sure: have not I said it? You had best make Mr. Woodall a Thief, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I make him nothing, Madam: but the Thief in my Dream was like Mr. Woodall; and that Thief may have made Mr. Limberham something.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Woodall is no Thief, that's certain: but if a Thief shou'd be turn'd to Mr. Woodall, that may be something.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Then I'll fetch out the Jewels: will that satisfie you?

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: That shall satisfie him.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Yes, that shall satisfie me.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Then you are a Predestinated Fool, and somewhat worse, that shall be nameless: do you not see how grosly she abuses you? My life on't, there's some-body within, and she knows it; otherwise she wou'd suffer you to bring out the Jewels.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, I am no Predestinated Fool; and therefore, Pug, give way.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I will not satisfie your humor.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Then I will satisfie it my self: for my generous blood is up, and I'll force my entrance.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Here's Bilbo then shall bar you: Atoms are not so small, as I will slice the Slave. Ha! Fate, and Furies!

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I, for all your Fate and Furies, I charge you, in his Majesties Name, to keep the Peace: now, disobey Authority, if you dare.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Fear him not, sweet Mr. Brainsick.

sp.speaker: Pleas. to Bra.
sp.p: But, if you shou'd hinder him, he may trouble you at Law, Sir, and say you robb'd him of his Jewels.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: That's well thought on. I will accuse him hainously; there— and therefore fear and tremble.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: My Allegiance Charms me: I acquiesce.— (Aside) Th' occasion's plausible to let him pass. Now let the burnish'd Beams upon his Brow blaze broad, for the brand he cast upon the Brainsick.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Limberham, come back, and hear me.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Yes, I will hear thee, Pug.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Go on; my life for yours, he's there.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I am deaf, as an Adder; I will not hear thee, nor have no commiseration.

div.stage: Struggles from her, and rushes in.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Then I know the worst, and care not.

div.stage: Limberham comes running out with the Jewels, follow'd by Woodall, with his Sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: O, save me, Pug, save me!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A Slave, to come and interrupt me at my Devotions! but I'll—

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Hold, hold, since you are so devout, for Heav'n sake, hold.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Nay, Mounsieur Woodall!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: For my sake, spare him.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Yes, for Pug's sake, spare me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I did his Chamber the honour, when my own was not open, to retire thither; and he to disturb me, like a profane Rascal as he was.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: (Aside) I believe he had the Devil for his Chaplain, and a man durst tell him so.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What's that you mutter?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay, nothing; but that I thought you had not been so well given. I was only afraid of Pug's Jewels.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What, does he take me for a Thief? nay then—

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: O, mercy, mercy.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; 'twas a foolish Dream of mine that set him on. I dreamt, a Thief, who had been just repriev'd for a former Robbery, was vent'ring his Neck a minute after in Mr. Lamberham's Closet.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Are you thereabouts, i'faith! A Pox of Artemiderus!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I have had a Dream too, concerning Mrs. Brainsick, and perhaps—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mrs. Tricksy, a word in private with you, by your Keepers leave.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, you may speak your pleasure to her; and, if you have a mind to go to prayers together, the Closet is open.

sp.speaker: Wood. to Tr.
sp.p: You but suspect it at most, and cannot prove it: if you value me, you will not ingage me in a quarrel with her Husband.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well, in hope you'l love me, I'll obey.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Now, Damsel Tricksy, your dream, your Dream!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: 'Twas something of a Elagelet that a Shepherd play'd upon so sweetly, that three Women follow'd him for his Musick, and still one of 'em snatch'd it from the other.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: (Aside) I understand her; but I find she's brib'd to secrecy.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: That Flagelet was, by interpretation, but let that pass; and Mr. Woodall there was the Shepherd that play'd the Tan ta ra upon't: but a generous heart, like mine, will endure the infamy no longer; therefore, Pug, I banish thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Then farewel.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Is that all you make of me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I hate to be tormented with your jealous humors, and am glad to be rid of 'em.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Bear witness, good People, of her ingratitude! Nothing vexes me, but that she calls me jealous; when I found him as close as a Butter-fly in her Closet.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No matter for that: I knew not he was there.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Wou'd I cou'd believe thee.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You have both our words for't.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why shou'd you perswade him against his will?

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Since you won't perswade me, I care not much: here are the Jewels in my possession; and I'll fetch out the Settlement immediately.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Showing the Box) Look you, Sir, I'll spare your pains: four hundred a year will serve to comfort a poor cast Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: I thought what wou'd come of your Devils Pater Nosters!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Restore it to him for pity, Woodall.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I make him my Trustee; he shall not restore it.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Here are Jewels that cost me above two thousand pound, a Queen might wear 'em; behold this Orient Neck-lace, Pug! 'tis pity any Neck shou'd touch it after thine, that pretty Neck! but, oh, 'tis the falsest Neck that e're was hang'd in Pearl.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Twoud become your bounty to give it her at parting.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Never the sooner for your asking. But, oh, that word Parting! can I bear it? if she cou'd find in her heart but so much grace, as to acknowledge what a Traytress she has been, I think in my Conscience I cou'd forgive her.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I'll not wrong my Innocence so much, nor this Gentlemans; but, since you have accus'd us falsly, four hundred a year, betwixt us two, will make us some part of reparation.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I answer you not, but with my Leg, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: (Aside) This mads me; but I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: What, wilt thou kill me, Pug, with thy unkindness, when thou know'st I cannot live without thee? It goes to my heart, that this wicked Fellow—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How's that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lim.
