sp.p: Under the Rose, good Mr. Woodall. But I speak it with all submission, in the bitterness of my spirit, that you, or any man, shou'd have the disposing of my four hundred a year gratis: therefore, dear Pug, a word in private, with your permission, good Mr. Woodall.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Alas, I know, by experience, I may safely trust my Person with you.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: O. Father Aldo, we have wanted you! Here has been made the rarest discovery!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: With the most Comical Catastrophe!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Happily arriv'd, i'faith, my old Sub-fornicator: I have been taken upon suspicion here with Mrs. Tricksy.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: To be taken, to be seen! Before George that's a point next the worst, Son Woodall.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Truth is, I wanted thy assistance, old Methusalem: but, my comfort is, I fell greatly.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Well, young Phaeton, that's somewhat yet, if you made a blaze at your departure.

div.stage: Enter Giles, Mrs. Brainsick, and Judith.

sp.speaker: Giles.
sp.p: By your leave, Gentlemen. I have follow'd an old Master of mine, these two long hours, and had a fair Course at him up the Street: here he enter'd I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Whoop Holiday! our trusty and well-beloved Giles, most welcome! Now, for some news of my ungracious Son.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) Giles here! O Rogue, Rogue! Now, wou'd I were safe stow'd, over head and ears, in the Chest again.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Look you now, Son Woodall, I told you I was not mistaken; my Rascal's in Town, with a vengeance to him.

sp.speaker: Giles.
sp.p: Why, this is he, Sir; I thought you had known him.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Known whom?

sp.speaker: Giles.
sp.p: Your Son here, my young Master.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Do I dote? or art thou drunk, Giles?

sp.speaker: Giles.
sp.p: Nay, I am sober enough, I'm sure; I have been kept fasting almost these two days.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, 'tis so! I read it in that leering look: What a Tartar have I caught!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Woodall his Son!

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: What, young Father Aldo!

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: (Aside) Now cannot I for shame hold up my head, to think what this young Rogue is privy to!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Brain.
sp.p: The most dumb interview I ever saw!

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: What, have you beheld the Gorgon's head on either side?

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Oh, my sins! my sins! and he keeps my Book of Conscience too! He can display 'em, with a witness! Oh, treacherous young Devil!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: (Aside) Well, the Squib's run to the end of the Line, and now for the Cracker: I must bear up.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I must set a face of Authority on the matter, for my credit.—Pray, who am I? do you know me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, I think I shou'd partly know, Sir: you may remember some private passages betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: (Aside) I thought as much; he has me already!— But pray, Sir, why this Ceremony amongst Friends? Put on, put on; and let us hear what news from France: have you heard lately from my Son? does he continue still the most hopeful and esteem'd young Gentleman in Paris? does he menage his allowance with the same discretion? and lastly, has he still the same respect and duty for his good old Father?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I have been too long from my Catechise, to answer so many questions; but, suppose there be no news of your Quondam Son, you may comfort up your heart for such a loss; Father Aldo has a numerous Progeny about the Town, Heav'n bless 'em.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Sir; I find you have been searching for your Relations then, in Whetstone's Park!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, Sir; I made some scruple of going to the foresaid place, for fear of meeting my own Father there.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, I cou'd find in my heart to disinherit thee.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Sure you cannot be so unnatural.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I am sure I am no Bastard; witness one good quality I have: If any of your Children have a stronger Tang of the Father in 'em, I am content to be disown'd.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Well, from this time forward, I pronounce thee—no Son of mine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then you desire I shou'd proceed, to justifie I am lawfully begotten? The Evidence is ready, Sir; and, if you please, I shall relate before this Honourable Assembly, those excellent Lessons of Morality you gave me at our first Acquaintance. As, in the first place,—

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p:
Hold hold; I charge thee hold, on thy obedience. I forgive
thee heartily: I have proof enough thou art my Son; but tame thee that can, thou art a mad one.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, this is as it shou'd be.

sp.speaker: Aldo to Him.
sp.p: Not a word of any passages betwixt us: 'tis enough we know each other; hereafter we'll banish all Pomp and Ceremony, and live familiarly together: I'll be Pilades, and thou mad Orestes, and we'll divide the Estate betwixt us, and have fresh Wenches, and Ballum Rankum every night.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A match, i'faith: and let the World pass.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: But hold a little; I had forgot one point: I hope you are not marri'd, nor ingag'd?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: To nothing but my pleasures, I.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: A mingle of profit wou'd do well though. Come, here's a Girl; look well upon her; 'tis a metled Toad, I can tell you that: she'll make notable work betwixt two Sheets, in a lawful way.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What, my old Enemy, Mrs. Pleasance!

sp.speaker: M. Brain.
sp.p: Marry Mrs. Saintly's Daughter!

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: The truth is, she has past for her Daughter, by my appointment; but she has as good blood running in her veins, as the best of you: her Father, Mr. Palms, on his Death-bed, left her to my care and disposal; besides, a Fortune of twelve hundred a year; a pretty convenience, by my faith.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Beyond my hopes, if she consent.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: I have taken some care of her Education, and plac'd her here with Mrs. Saintly, as her Daughter, to avoid her being blown upon by Fops, and younger Brothers. So now, Son, I hope I have match'd your Concealment with my discovery! there's hit for hit, e're I cross the Cudgels.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: You will not take 'em up, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I dare not against you, Madam: I'm sure you'll worst me at all Weapons. All I can say is, I do not now begin to love you.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Let me speak for thee: Thou shalt be us'd, little Pleasance, like a Soveraign Princess: thou shalt not touch a bit of Butchers meat in a twelvemonth; and thou shalt be treated—

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Not with Ballum Rankum every night, I hope!

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Well, thou art a Wag; no more of that. Thou shalt want neither Man's meat, nor Woman's meat, as far as his provision will hold out.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: But I fear he's so horribly given to go a House-warming abroad, that the least part of the Provision will come to my share at home.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You'll find me so much imployment in my own Family, that I shall have little need to look out for Journey-work.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: Before George, he shall do thee Reason, e're thou sleep'st.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
No; he shall have an Honourable Truce for one day at
least; for 'tis not fair, to put a fresh Enemy upon him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bra. to Pleas.
sp.p: I beseech you, Madam, discover nothing betwixt him and me.

sp.speaker: Pleas. to her.
sp.p: I am contented to cancel the old Score; but take heed of bringing me an after-reckoning.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Save you, Gentlemen; and you, my Quondam Master: you are welcome all, as I may say.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: How now, Sirrah? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Give good words, while you live, Sir: your Landlord, and Mr. Saintly, if you please.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Oh, I understand the business; he's marri'd to the Widow.

sp.speaker: Saint.
sp.p: Verily, the good work is accomplish'd.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: But, why Mr. Saintly?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: When a man is marri'd to his Betters, 'tis but decency to take her name. A pretty House, pretty Scituation, and prettily furnish'd! I have been unlawfully labouring at hard duty; but a Parson has soder'd up the matter: thank your Worship, Mr. Woodall.— How? Giles here!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The business is out, and I am now Aldo: my Father has forgiven me, and we are friends.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: When will Giles, with his honesty, come to this?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay, do not insult too much, good Mr. Saintly: thou wert but my Deputy; thou know'st the Widow intended it to me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But I am satisfi'd she perform'd it with me, Sir. Well, there is much good will in these precise old Women; they are the most zealous Bed-fellows: Look and she does not blush now! you see there's Grace in her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mr. Limberham, where are you? Come, chear up man: how go matters on your side of the Country? Cry him, Gervase.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Mr. Limberham, Mr. Limberham, make your appearance in the Court, and save your Recognizance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sir, I shou'd now make a Speech to you in my own defence; but the short of all is this: if you can forgive what's past, your hand, and I'll endeavour to make up the breach betwixt you and your Mistress: if not, I am ready to give you the satisfaction of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p:
Sir, I am a peaceable man, and a good Christian, though I say it, and desire no satisfaction from any man: Pug and I are partly agreed upon the point already; and therefore lay thy hand upon thy
heart, Pug, and if thou canst from the bottom of thy Soul defie mankind, naming no body, I'll forgive thy past Enormities; and, to give good example to all Christian Keepers, will take thee to my wedded Wife: And thy four hundred a year shall be setled upon thee, for separate maintenance.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why, now I can consent with Honour.

sp.speaker: Aldo.
sp.p: This is the first business that was over made up without me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Give you Joy, Mr. Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: You may spare your breath, Sir, if you please: I desire none from you. 'Tis true, I'm satisfi'd of her Vertue, in spight of Slander; but, to silence Calumny, I shall civilly desire you henceforth, not to make a Chappel of Ease of Pug's Closet.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: (Aside) I'll take care of false Worship, I'll warrant him: he shall have no more to do with Bell and the Dragon.

sp.speaker: Brain.
sp.p: Come hither, Wedlock, and let me Seal my lasting Love upon thy Lips: Saintly has been seduc'd, and so has Tricksy: — but thou alone art kind and constant. Hitherto I have not valu'd modesty, according to its merit; but hereafter, Memphis shall not boast a Monument more firm, than my affection.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A most excellent Reformation, and at a most seasonable time! The Moral on't is pleasant, if well consider'd. Now, let's to Dinner: Mr. Saintly, lead the way, as becomes you, in your own House.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Your hand, sweet moyety.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: And heart too, my comfortable Importance.
Mistress, and Wife, by turns, I have possess'd:
He who enjoys 'em both, in one, is bless'd.

div.head: PROLOGUE.

l.hi: TRue Wit has seen its best days long ago,
It ne're look'd up, since we were dipt in Show:
When Sense in Dogrel Rhimes and Clouds was lost,
And Dulness flourish'd at the Actors cost.
Nor stopt it here, when Tragedy was done,
Satyre and Humour the same Fate have run;
And Comedy is sunk to Trick and Pun.
Now our Machining Lumber will not sell,
And you no longer care for Heav'n or Hell;
What Stuff will please you next, the Lord can tell.
Let them, who the Rebellion first began,
To wit, restore the Monarch if they can;
Our Author dares not be the first bold Man.
He, like the prudent Citizen, takes care,
To keep for better Marts his Staple Ware,

div.l: His Toys are good enough for Sturbridge Fair,
Tricks were the Fashion; if it now be spent,
'Tis time enough at Easter to invent;
No Man will make up a new Suit for Lent:

l.hi: If now and then he takes a small pretence
To forrage for a little Wit and Sense,
Pray pardon him, he meant you no offence.

div.l: Next Summer Nostradamus tells, they say.
That all the Criticks shall he shipt away,

l.hi: And not enow be left to damn a Play.
To every Sayl beside, good Heav'n be kind;
But drive away that Swarm with such a Wind,

div.l: That not one Locust may be left behind.

div.head: EPILOGUE. Spoken by LIMBERHAM.

l.hi: I Beg a Boon, that e're you all disband,
Some one would take my Bargain off my hand;
To keep a Punk is but a common evil,
To find her false, and Marry, that's the Devil.
Well, I ne're Acted Part in all my life,
But still I was fobb'd off with some such Wife:
I find the Trick; these Poets take no pity
Of one that is a Member of the City.
We Cheat you lawfully, and in our Trades,
You Cheat us basely with your Common Jades.
Now I am Married, I must sit down by it;
But let me keep my Dear-bought Spouse in quiet:

div.l: Let none of you Damn'd Woodalls of the Pit,

l.hi: Put in for Shares to mend our breed, in Wit;
We know your Bastards from our Flesh and Blood,
Not one in ten of yours e're comes to good.
In all the Boys their Fathers Vertues shine,

div.l: But all the Female Fry turn Pugs like mine.

l.hi: When these grow up, Lord with what Rampant Gadders
Our Counters will be throng'd, and Roads with Padders.
This Town two Bargains has, not worth one farthing,

div.l: A Smithfield Horse, and Wife of Covent-Garden.
